div.p: THE VARIETIE, A COMOEDY, Lately preſented by His Majeſties Servants at the Black-Friers.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moſeley, and are to be ſold at his Shop at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church|yard. 1649.

list.item: SIr William, A Sutor to the Lady Beau|field.
Maſter Newman, A Sutor to Miſtris Lucy.
Formall, Gentleman-uſher to the Lady Beaufield.

div.head: Act I. Scaene I.
div.stage: Enter Sir William (at one doore:) Mr Manly (at the other.)

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: I Ack Manly, well met.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Noble Sir William the hum|bleſt of your ſervants.

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: Come, thou ſhalt along with me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: To ſee my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: May you thrive in your courtſhip to her: at this time I am engag'd to other buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Can any thing concerne a Gentleman equall with a handſome Lady?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, the receiving of money is more conſiderable with me at this time, than all the women in the world. But who is your Miſtris Knight?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p:
I dare tell thee, Madam Beaufield, the
Lady of ſpirit, and entertainment, the only Mag|netick widdow i'th Town.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They talk her a wit, and a moſt ſuperſti|tious obſerver of perſons, and their garbes; I ne|ver had the happineſs to kiſs her hand, or be known to her, but I converſe with ſome who are very high and loud in her character; another time Enter Jeere Major, and Minor. Ile wait upon you. Who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: In what grott haſt thou ſpent thy time, that thou art ignorant of theſe people? Theſe two are held the wits; That is the remarkable Jeerer of the Town, and 'has purchas'd to himſelf the title of a Jeere Major.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, Is there a Regiment of Jeerers?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: You ſhall pardon me, there are ſets of them, as there are of Fidlers; there is firſt a ſet of Court Jeerers, ſpruce half-witted men, con|fident, and fierce in their opinions; theſe are men that make themſelves muſick, and their cloths make roome for their wic; and go before in all compa|nies: Then there is the town Jeerers, like Ho|boyes or Waites of the City, that think they are wiſe when they are loud, and make a noiſe when they come to Plaies, to diſtract the next mans underſtanding. There are Jeerers at time of the yeer that go down into the Countrey, and in|fect Wakes, and Faires, and the Sizes, with their impudence, with which they ſave charges, and are never without the name of a great Lord, to whom they are coſin Germane.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But what has he deſerved to be called 〈◊〉Jeere Major, and to beare ſuch a title? I have ſeen the Rooke.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: An excellent ill nature has preferd him to opinion: the other has merited but the name of a Jeere minor; yet they can ſee me pleaſant in their reproaches, and laugh in their own defence, which many times keeps off the cudgell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, Jeering is a bleſſing that every man may have if he give his mind to it: but wit (if I remember what I was taught) happens not to one amongſt five hundred on 'em. But I forget my affaire.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Shall's meet and be merry this Evening.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Theres no muſick in me without my ſing|ing birds about me, then I am a Lord, and when I put on my habit of Leiſter, I am his own excel|lence.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Doſt thou preſerve that him or ſtill?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I may chance by the falſe light of the Evening march to thy Lodging.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Doſt know where tis? I am remov'd. (whiſper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So, no diſcoveries what Prince I am.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: A match: that ſhape will beget us ſome mirch.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your moſt humble ſervant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: My Miſtris is ſomewhat melancholy, if he come in that phantaſticall habit, we ſhall have rare ſport beyond his expectation, to have the La|dies laugh at him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: This is very fine wit yſaith, and ſoone learnd I thinke; a little more on't ſweet Gentle|men.

sp.speaker: Jeer.
sp.p:
Suppoſe you were foxd laſt night; thus I come to you, and accoſt; Save you Sir; you muſt
know I muſt laugh all the while; how fare you Sir? Do not ſome fumigations remaine, ſome va|pours not diſſipated, a kind of Vertigo, a weak|ning of the Nerves, or ſo? Ha, ha, ha, what thinks your Worſhip of milke now, thin broth, or a Julip of pitifull Six for a penance to ſettle you, or a haire of the ſame whelp? Ha, ha, ha, there's wit for you.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's no harme in the world in it, nor no exceptions if you laugh in the right place.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Now imagine you met an honourable Gentleman that had got a hurt in the groine; thus I invade you; but the laugh muſt hold me too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By any meanes, I cannot chooſe but laugh my ſelf.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: There is no ſafe jeering without it.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Sir, you have been at puſh of pike and received a hurt, upon ſome unſlaught in ſome fe|male ſervice, Ha, ha, ha; your breath is Aroma|tick ſince you kiſs'd your Miſtris, and your water out-ſmells the violet, ha, ha, ha; by the powerfull—yclipped Turpentine, tis true; what pitty tis you went without a charme, or had no acquaintance with a Laplander, to make you Venus-ſhot-free? Ha, ha, ha; and how many french tenniſtalls have you in your flanke now? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You ſate up at play all night, and loſt your money; another now.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Not I a penny, I ſent a buffe Gentleman that lookt big upon me, after an ill hand, twenty peeces upon halfe a dozen oaths.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p:
A good pawne, keep his oaths, if he do not pay your money, take the forfeit, and if he be
a Gameſter he'll be undone for want of ſwearing.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Suppoſe it loſt?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Me thinks Cavallier you looke pale ſince you came from the charnelhouſe, did the bones affright you? you are a moſt religious Gentleman when you are at dice, and do ſo pray for 3 fives 3 foures at in and in: with what devoti|on you look on the ſeven of Spades and eight of Diamonds at cribbiſh? ha, ha; how zealouly you invoke the Saints to fit you with cards at picket, or lebet.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I invoke the Saints?

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: I ſpeake to the catholicke gameſter, that underſtands all games.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By the way though, doe you think there are any gameſters in heaven?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: It is to be feared, they may loſe ſo much upon earth, they will hardly purchaſe a place there, or if any get thither, (which muſt be excellent throwing) he would be more call'd upon, and perhaps puld downe agen, upon every diſpute at play to be Groome porter.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: How like you theſe?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You ſhall both with me to my Miſtris, and help to Jeere my rivalls.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Your Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I Miſtris Luoy, Lady Beaufeilds daugh|ter, my Landlady Miſtris Ʋoluble has commend|ed me to her, and I hope to carry her, if one Gentl. that ſhe loves better do not get her away?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Wee'l jeere him to death.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
That were an excellent way, I thinke there is no ſtatute againſt that, I care not what becomes on him, he put bitter jeſts upon me to|ther
day before the Ladies, and I making uſe of your wit Gentlemen, he told me to my face, that I talk'd nothing but clinches; as I am a Gentleman he did.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Oh barbarous!

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: You ſhall wound him with his owne weapon, and by a direction we can give you, you ſhall ſo jeere him, that he ſhall offer boote to change underſtandings with you.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Wee'l make him ſo ridiculous, he ſhal laugh at himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: That will be rare; I have ſent for my Mother to towne to be acquainted with La|dies, and learn dreſſing; my Landlady, hath pro|miſed to commend a Gentlewoman to waite upon her, and teach her the art of painting, and all the poſtures of a great woman; I do meane ſhe ſhall marry ſome Knight or other, and be Ladified.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: It wil be neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Though I ſay it, the woman is flexible, and has been in her daies—My Father might have been a Knight, and he had not been an Aſſe, and lov'd his mony; but we loſe time, let's to my Miſtres Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: We attend ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The ſame day, a Dolphin taken in a net at Woolidge, and ten live Pilchards in a Salmons belly—ſtrange things! the 13. of July, the Caramountaine kittend in the Tower: an Eele|ſhip ſpring a leak ſhooting the Bridge,—heere are prodigious things. Enter Newman.
Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Mr. Uſher, how does your Lady?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: She is in health.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: And Miſtris Lucy?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Both in the Garden. Sir you have good intelligence, what newes abroad? a touch to your ſervant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Alas you are acquainted with the ſtate myſteries.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Troth Sir, I know little, or if I did, I would be loath to ſpeake it, but to a friend, the times are dangerous.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Y'are right Mr. Formall, but be not nice, I know you are furniſh'd with newes, as well as ſome that give penſions, though 'twere to a Cap|taine in theſe warlike-times, to have it made for 'em; you being a quotidian ambler upon imperti|nent viſits, muſt needs gleane the ſecrets of the court and ſtate.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sir I dare truſt you with any thing, but pray do not ſpeak on't; there is a great man in the world—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Think you ſo?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: That—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me; but—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat his name?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me for that too; a word to the wiſe; you can gueſſe what I meane, and let that paſſe; and now we talke of ſtate af|faires, there is a packet come out of the North, and abox—in your eare ſir.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What is ſaid to be in that packet?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ther's the buſineſſe, but that no body knowes.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Tak't upon my word; you are a friend, I heare further at Mr. Secretaries, but you muſt ſay nothing of it, you undoe me if you doe, the King goes to Hampton Court next weeke, but how long he ſtayes is uncertaine. Sir, you ſee I put my ſelfe into your hands.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But is this done like a wiſeman to reveale theſe myſteries, to truſt theſe ſecrets to one you have not known above 7 Yeare, if I ſhould inform what will become of you, and your eſtate? oh you muſt be cautious, though for my part—

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Oh Sir! I know to whom I ſpeak, and will tell you more, for I dare truſt you with my ſoule; they ſay the Northerne progreſſe holds this yeare, and that the Elke is dead in the new great parke

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Tis as I tell you, by the fall of a tree, doe not you remember a tempeſt foure nights agoe? then 'twas, bluſtring times Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That makes Ʋan Trumpe ſo troubled with the winde colicke, but now the Hollanders, as they report, have many Engineers and Ma|thematitians ſet a work, how to keep and vent it at their pleaſure, and ſo to ſerve in Navigation for their ſhips, that there may be ventus liber, as well as ventus clauſus, anſwerable to the two Seas.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ha, ha! that's newes indeed, alas mine is but domeſtick, but what do you heare of London Bridge? it is whiſper'd by ſome it will, and ſome againe point blank ſay it will not be repaired; but make not me the Authour.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
And I do heare the Camells decay at
Tiballs: but pray no more of it from me.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall not doubt me Sir, you do not heare of the Dolphin—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Of France?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Taken as Woolidge in a net.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Of Italian cutworke.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The newes is not common of the Pil|chards, the Catamountaine, nor the Eeleſhip?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall heare more; I am your ſervant. Here is Miſtris Lucy Sir, and Miſtris Ʋoluble.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: I confeſſe he has no overcharge of wit, that will be your happineſſe, he has a good eſtate, and you may live with more delight than a court Lady, he is a handſome man too, I am bound to give you my adviſe, for your mothers ſake, whoſe ſervant I am by many obligations, ſhe has been my cuſtomer for face-water, and pomatum theſe many yeares.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But if you be ſo skilfull, as you are profeſt, and read in the ſecrets of nature, you can tell by your art where I ſhall fixe my affection, doe not you know Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: I never ſee the Gentleman, but I am not ignorant that he matches in the Vanne, and leades the file of your amorous ſervants, but—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: If you love your ſelfe.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He is a well-bred Gentleman, and one deſerves my good opinion, hee's here.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They obſerve me— Exit Form:
I kiſſe your hand faire Miſtris Lucy: whats ſhe that lookes ſo like one of the Sibills?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Is this the Gentleman you declare ſo civill, and well-bred, Lady? If I have any skill take heed on him, he has an unlucky countenance.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: This Gypſey will but cozen you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: She is excellent cunning, and has foretold ſtr ange things, beleeve it.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: If my Miſtris have an opinion of her Art, ſhe may do me a diſpleaſure; I have heard much talk of this woman, ſome ſay ſhe is a Witch too, and weares the Devill in her thumbe Ring, I would not anger one of her Familiars. Take no of|fence Miſtris at the rudeneſſe of my Language, this Lady ſhall give a very faire pawne, the word of a Gentlewoman, that I ſhall be of good beha|viour, if you pleaſe not to interpret me too ha|ſtily.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There is ſome texs in your forehead Sir that wants a comment, but Ile not ſo much ſtudy your ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Nay, thou ſhalt not be diſpleaſed with him.

div.stage: Enter Lady Beaufield, and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Alas, I am not angry; heres my Lady and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You are Maſter of an excellent language Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: You honour me too much, it is becauſe you are the excellent Subject Madam, and being the perfection of your Sexe, an argument to create Eloquence in every tongue.

sp.speaker: Beau
sp.p: Then I muſt think you flatter; theſe prai|ſes are miſplac'd. I ſhall ſuſpect you love me not, or are not wiſe.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Why Madam?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You take ſuch paines, and make a pilgri|mage to thats within your reach; I muſt confeſs I like Diſcourſe, but think not all my ſoule plac'd in my eare; although I love a Lute well, it fol|lows not I ſhould dote upon a Cimball.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: A Cimball?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And dance as I were ſtong with a Taran|tula, when you are at it, roſting of a Galliard? You overdo this inſtrument, give me your courtſhip in a phraſe is fit to own and underſtand.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Your pardon Madam; I affect not bold and over-rack'd Hyperboles, although I might in|ſiſt upon the wealth and fulneſs of your merits, to which, all praiſe, that can flow from me, is Ju|ſtice, ſuch command you have upon your humble Servant, I rather wiſh my tongue a forfeit to per|petuall ſilence, then with one harſh ſound offend your eare; you'l give me leave I hope to ſay I love you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This is Engliſh Sir, and ſome do call it ſence; 'tis faire, and fit, when any Lady's private with her Servant; 'tis what I learn'd a child, I have not yet outgrown the knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Did you love ſo young?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
I underſtand the meaning of your lan|guage, 'tis not perplext, and you may love me too, and tell me ſo, and I may underſtand you; what need compartments here, freeſes, and words of Architecture, that will make things hard to the un|derſtanding? As you could not build a ſence in love without 'em? Yet I bar not the freedom of Diſ|courſe, and uſe of Metaphors: And you may praiſe us too in Verſe, or Proſe, to ſhew the exal|tation of your wit in company, but 'tis the worſt
diſcourſe when we are private.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: If I had confidence ſhe would direct me—action I beleeve when opportunity In|vites—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To what good Knight? be not miſtaken, I commend courtſhip in words, that are made round like pills fit to be ſwallowed, and not rag|ged bullets.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange Lady, I know not how to take her.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: My Lady? Madam—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Art thou come?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Is it your Ladiſhips pleaſure I ſhall read to day?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: By any meanes, the Ladies will not faile, we ſhould forget our Academy: Sir William we muſt entreat your patience, and Ma|ſter Newman. Vol. whiſpers to Sr Wil.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Madam, the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Say I wait upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Ile take my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You will engage him to credulity, and prepare ſome mirth.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Mounſier Galliard the Dancer attends Madam.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: He muſt give way to another exerciſe; Sir William you ſhall do us a favour if you pleaſe to entertaine a little time with him in the next Chamber, our Lecture will not be long, and ſweet Mr Newman the French-man will delight you with his diſcourſes, he has a tongue as confident as his feet, if you can but humour him.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: You ſhall command us Madam.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That Done wee'l joine ſocieties and mirth. Come Mrs Voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I hope you will excuſe my imperfecti|ons. Exeunt.

div.head: Act II. Scaene I.
div.stage: Table and ſix Chaires ſet out. Enter Lady Beaufield, Lucy, and other Ladies, Miſtris Voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
IT is an infinite favour, (moſt excellent Ladies) and muſt needs ſpeak the ſweet|neſs of your nature and diſpoſitions, that y'are pleas'd to hear me, ſo weak and un|worthy of the Chaire, rather deſerving to be in the number of Diſciples, than a profeſſor in any of the female ſciences; but as your ver|tues are more exemplary, in this honour to me, the humbleſt of your Servants, it will become me, in the gratitude to ſo noble a bounty, not to waſte time, but ſuccinctly to deliver, what I could not finiſh without treſpaſſe on your patience; at my laſt reading I did conclude with old Ladies, that will cozen Nature, and Time, and abuſe the men they love beſt; to theſe I only add, it is not Mercu|ry to change their skins like Snakes, but they muſt fill up wrinckles as well as hide gray haires: your red leather is for Countrey Wenches, your white waſh, or Spaniſh Fucus is the beſt, but a tire wo|man,
or coverer of time or nakedneſs muſt be kept in penſion: ſor it is now faſhionable to buy one of her apprencice Girles out of her time, as Lords and Gentlemen do Barbers boyes. Amongſt other ornaments, Ribbands challenge no meane place, the variety, and blaſon of theſe, I have elſewhere examined. For your fineſt Laces, the Angel in Cheape, but they muſt be dearer then o|thers, becauſe they come in Coaches, for pride or ſtatelineſs in any thing adds charges. Touching Gloves, might I adviſe, I would have a few ſelect|ed Ladies, to procure ſome ingenious Gentleman at a reaſonable penſion to lye Lerger for them at Rome for Frangepane Gloves, and ſuch other cor|reſpondent things as may be of moment and great conſequence to your Ladyſhips: But then I muſt advertiſe, and moſt ſeriouſly, that he may be a man of parts, and ſomewhat ſmelling toward the Roman Waſh, that he may give you intelli|gence of that State, and humours of the Gardi|nals, or thoſe that pretend to it, be they little or great, for this concernes the ſtate Ladies here: For your ſwarfie Mountebanke Italian, he utters ſophiſticated Holborne Gloves for Frangepane, Eſſe● Cheeſe for Parmeſan, rotten poſt for ſweet powder, pickled white Leather for Muſhromes, and cozens more with his broken Engliſh, then the wits can get honeſily with their beſt language.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.p: The Merchant of Italian Saulſages, A meet Quack.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
But then I would adviſe your Ladiſhips to have another Gentleman ſent into Spaine for perfumes, pocket Fannes, orange flower water, Orange flower butter beauty, Aqua de Chedrey,
and many provocatives, as Contra yerua, and Joco lata.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.p: It is a very learned Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: For Holland, 'tis too deare in Spaine, there|fore for a conſcionable cozenage over and above, here are honeſt Dutchmen will ſerve you moſt faithfully. For Jewels, you may buy them at what rates you pleaſe, they add luſtre to a Lady, and you may ſell them at a fift or ſift part, which is very well for a great Madam, if you would put them off at the beſt rate, you muſt get ſome Do|ctor of Phiſick, or broking Apocriphall Captain, to ſhew them (as if there were fornication in it) behind the doore, hanging or curtaine, which makes his fingers like Jewellers cardes to ſet rings on, for there are bawdes for rings and Jewels, as well as for other commodities.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What do you think of this caution Ma|dam?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: For your Linnen, it muſt be fine, and freſh every day, therein conſiſts humane delight. For linnen breeches, though ſome think them cleanly, in my opinion they imitate a Dutch Stove too much. For Aprons, plaine Holland is moſt be|comming, ſtarch'd Lawne was in Queen Elizabeths time, and will not endure rumpling, every thing muſt be ſquar'd by uſe and elegance; but for your white Shoes, rich Roſes, light-coloured ſilk Stock|ings, and ſuch variety below ſtaires, they are great Inducers, as a learned man told me, (I will not ſay a Divine) for Love, moſt excellent Ladies, doth ſometimes aſcend, as well as deſcend.

But ſtill remember Ladies, that your Fanne be ſo little, as not to loſe the leaſt ſmirke, or grace
of your countenance for it, for then being ſo ſmall, when you put it to your face, ſome Courtiers may take it for a black patch. Then for your oaths, I proteſt is out of faſhion, I profeſſe for a Juſtice of Peaces Wiſe, I vow too maſculine, yfaith for a Chambermaid, Introth for a Landerer, As you hope to live, too like a Prayer; Never ſtir, would diſadvantage a Lady many waies, beſides viſits; For the active wenches of the time, May they be damn'd eternally, and loſe all their deſigns if it be not ſo; Upon my honour ſounds well, which in a great Lady can never be forfeited if ſhe be in love, for great women have their privilege of Nobility, and can never be forſworn like the Com|mon people.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is Perjury in women no breach of Laws?

sp.speaker: 4 Lady.
sp.p: You have the Doctors opinion.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: One touch, if you grow old, which I omit|ted formerly, When time, which is the moath of beauty, creeps upon you, you muſt be ſure to have ſo many leaves and curtaines before your windows, that you may ſhew your ſelves at more varions lights than the moſt cozening Mercer his faded and deceitfull Wares, for the youth of your white Satin will be then but pearle colour at the beſt, it may be but aſh-colour, and therefore re|fuſe no advantage to give it gloſs, according to the concluſion of a moderne Poet, which at this pre|ſent ſhall be mine.

quote.l: Wiſe Ladies muſt refuſe no Art
For age will ſnow upon their heart:

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
You have done us a great honour, and Ladies you ſhall not deny me this favour to taſte of a ſmall banquet that waites upon you in the
next roome, ſhall I ſhew the way. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir William, Mr. Newman, Monſieur Galliard.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me be content to have de litell patience, and be my trot, me tell you, vat me have ſeene a to day, de fine ſport in devarle, me come into de great man to day, me make de reverence Ala|mode, come ill faut, and he make me de eſtrange a Sir reverence de tird time, dat ever you ſaw.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: That was not civill.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Oh Monſieur, every man has not the activity of your feet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: By my fat, 'tis very eſtrange a ding, dat dey will ſuffer a des men to be neere a de King, a de Queene, de Prince, or de Princeſſe, dey vil marra de underſtanding very muſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Why Mounſieur that lyes at the o|ther end.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you ſhall excuſe a me, for de Courtier Alamode, dere de vit lie in de foot, begar dere is nobodie can be viſeman, dat does no make a de moſt excellent reverence, dat is moſt certaine, dat is the beſt ting in de hole varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I am cleare of his opinion.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But do you think Caeſar Sir, or moſt of the Emperors or worthies of the world, ſtudied the liberall ſcience of the foot, or puiſſant toe?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: No, but begar dat make dem dye all un|fortunate, for if dey had tinke of noting but de reverence, dey might ha live a great a while.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Excellent well argued, and very cleare in my underſtanding.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
I confeſſe the wiſedome of it Sir, but
for the wit do you thinke that lyes there?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dat be de beſt vit can be poſſible, for your vit, vat is your vit? your vit is to breake a de jeaſt, vel, looke you now a me, me vil breake a de jeaſt, dat is like dat a me lor, dat is like dat of de Knight, dat is like dat of de Ientilman, ha, ha, ha! dere is now one, two, tre very good jeaſts, by my trot dey are ſo very good jeaſt, dat make a me ſicke wide laugh, and begar me vil make a de page, de lacquey, & all de foole in de court, breake a des very good jeaſt, very quickly, dat is a noting.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: To any purpoſe?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What doe you thinke of the grave Aldermen? they are wiſe, and yet they doe not trouble themſelves much about legs.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Be my trot, me ſpeake a to de King, and to de Queene, to give me a patten, dat none ſhall teach a de Aldermen to make a de reverence but my ſelfe, and me vil undertake dat vid in one 12 a mont, but den dey muſt doe nothing elſe, dey ſhall make a de reverence, vid de Aldermen in de paris, and dance a Coran, a Cereban, a Moun|tague, and dat vil be very brave.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: VVhat faculties ſome men have?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But what ſhall buſineſſe do in the meane time Mounſieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Is not dis very great a buſineſſe? may be|gar, me vil undertake to de King and to de Queen to make a my Lor Mayre de Sheriff and de Al|dermen very fine a mask.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: And to write it Mounſieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Aw, de write? dat is noting alamode, your ſpeeſh two, tre, yard long, pſhaw? give a me de quick a ſpirit, de fancie, de brave ſcene,
de varietie of de Antimaſque, de nimble a foot, no matre de ſence, begar it vole be de brave||ting in de chriſtian varle.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: There is no queſtion to be made.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: And be my trot if me have a noder patten for de counſell learned in the law, for to teach dem de reverence, dat vil be very great varke, but my diligence, and skill in dat matre, have no deſpaire, to effect in time dis great benefit, and dat vil make a de law flouriſh; and Englan a brave Englan, begar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I won't doubt your abilityes, but I feare the capacity of the Gentlemen you undertake.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: But what will you look for now, for your paines Mounſieur? that is conſiderable.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar me looke for very muſh, for tis muſh paine, and tis brave ting, beſide me looke for a ſtatur of de braſſe, in de pallace yard, ven me goe out of dis varle.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: You will deſerve it as a rare patriot; but what manner of reverence would you have the grave lawyers to Imitate, you muſt conſider their robes:

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Obſerve a me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Such a reverence under your favour, would not become men of their gravity, one al|wayes lookes for a Coranto after it, and provokes a man to whiſtle, or fing when he ſees it, and makes one thinke ſtill, what you would have a moneth, a little too much of the activity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you no underſtand de matre, vere is your breine? dere is noting in de varle like a dat motion, for de Ientillman, and for de Ientilvoman.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p:
Yes by your leave ſir there is ſome|thing
elſe that is as good for them.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I vil tell you now, begar, here is a de kinſman dat is a me, and he live here very much time, before he come, dey vent in vid deir toes, and hold der cloke juſt a dere, and de hat ſo, fie, le diable! and now dey valk vid deir toes out for brave genty, you call dat a de ſplay foot, but me vonder dat de Lady no come, begar me no uſe to dis patience, and de vaite, pray tell you Madam dat me have autre buſines vid de Lor, and de autre Lady have de uſe of my foot begar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Oh Monſieur by no means.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Let us prevaile.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Tis no good you hold a me, begar, me no ſtay two minute to ſave a your ſoule, dat is de re|ſolution of de Cavalier de France.— Exit

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Would any man beleeve there ſhould be ſo much folly in this Cubit ſquare?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Do you think he is a French Dancer? let that anſwer you, and wonder he has no more Caprichios. But theſe Ladies are very tedious, we muſt have this Lecture put down.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: They are more like to purchaſe Greſham Colledg, and enlarge it for publick Profeſſors, you may live to ſee another Univerſity built, and only women commence Doctors.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But now we talk of learned women, you have been acquainted with Miſtris Voluble, has ſhe the abilities the women talk of? they ſay ſhe is a Fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p:
She is for more then Artificiall VVhite and Red, ſome think her guilty of the Black-Art, ſhe has foretold ſo many ſtrange things; ſhe has had two Husbands, and propheſied long before, how,
and when they ſhould give up the Ghoſt, if ſhe be not a Witch ſhe has the more wrong, for ſhe is be|leev'd a devilliſh cunning woman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Poſſible!

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: There's no● a Lady with child but con|ſults her Aſtrology, whether it ſhall be male or female; and the waiting women how long they ſhall keep their maidenheads, and who ſhall fa|ther the firſt borne, the Maſter or the ſervingman; ſhe is held a Sibill in the City, and tells oracu|louſly whether the Husband or the VVife ſhall die firſt, how, when, and where, and all this ſome|time by obſervation of the hand, or forehead; ſhe can ſee a maid through a maske, and is excel|lent at ſtolne goods, for ſhe can ſee a theefe through a millſtone as well as a conjuring glaſſe; in brief, ſhe is held prodigious at Divination, and moſt ſpecially ſeldome failes in her Judgment of the two deſtinies, Matrimony, and Hanging, this I have heard Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sr William Your Servant, Maſter Newman? that's he.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Jeere him ſoundly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat Gentlemen are theſe?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: He has betraid his ignorance already, he does not know us.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: VVhat, not the Major, and the Minor?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Not the Major, nor the Minor.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Cede majori Sir, Cede majori.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Parce minori Sir, Parce minori.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Here will be a fine concluſion from theſe premiſes, and they were worth conſidering.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Theſe two are wits.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Are they your wits? Pray heaven you may not loſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: If you love wit obſerve a little, and if I do not make you laugh, never laugh while you live.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You ſhall here how I will jeere Newman, my Rivall now; ſuch wit, wit of the laſt Edition: Let me have faire play, and theſe moſt ingenious friends of mine ſhall be judges.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: I think ſo, 'twill paſſe time till the La|dies come.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Mr Newman, you are a pretty Scholler, pray what is wit?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: A thing you want.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: A very pretty Probleme.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVill you or theſe Gentlemen be bound to underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, that's a clinch, to under|ſtand me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A clinch?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: I underſtand none.

sp.speaker: Simpl.
sp.p: Oh ſir, a palpable clinch; Ha, ha, ha, aske my friend.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is that your opinion?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Theres another clinch yfaith, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Pray ſir, what is't a clock?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: The myſtery of this?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat is a clinch ſir, do you know what 'tis?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
I neither know, nor care what 'tis, ſo I laugh, and ſweare 'tis a clinch, that's diſgrace and reproach enough to any man. With what eaſe can we cry up our own wit and anothers down, only by
ſaying that's a clinch. I think I ha jeerd him.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Oh the waies to wit are much ſhortned in theſe latter times, 'tis a picant age.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They have a gunpowder-plot to blow up ſence; pray Gentlemen take truce with your ſpleenes, and the wiſeſt of you three informe me what is wit; you have; no patience to heare me; or if you will not define it, ſpeake ſomething that is witty, and in faſhion.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Ile tell you then:

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You ſpeak Engliſh to be underſtood, O baſe!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat language is your wit?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Engliſh, but elaborate, for example—now beat up your kettle drums.

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: Sir, if my opticks faile not, I have read
Each myſtick line within your brow, my Genius
Is much exalted at your gaudy Phiſnomy;
Shal's to the houſe of mighty noiſe and ſurfets,
There tinctiour ſouls with bloud of purple grape?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat's all this?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I thought you were ignorant.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Give him the Paraphraſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: All this is, he remembers perfectly he has ſeene you before.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And deſires you but to go to the Tavern, and drink a pint of wine; here's language!

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat a deale of Embroydery is ſpent upon I am glad to ſee you well; How long has this been a vulgar language? You would court a Miſtris rarely in this Cabale.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: But how ſhall a man beget ſuch high conceits?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Have you a deſire to know Sir William? ſhall I tell him?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer
sp.p: If he will make it a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Why, turne your ſelfe round as faſt as you can, and the firſt things you ſpeak, your head being diſſie, will be theſe.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What a beavy of Buffoons have we here?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: VVe are at your mercy Gentlemen; but you that had a patience to expect ſo long, cannot want vertue to forgive, ſince we had no intent to make ſo great a treſpaſſe; where's Monſieur Gal|liard?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Madam, he's gone, ſomething diſpleas'd you had no more regard to a Gentleman of his quality; his time was pretious, and ſome other Lords and Ladies expected him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: His abſence will admit of eaſie pardon, 'tis a moſt ſuperſtitious foole; what Gent. are theſe?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: They are things were meant by nature, Madam, a cure for melancholly, we have had ſuch ſport and non-ſence with 'em

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: VVe ſhall loſe time upon 'em, pleaſe you, wee'l take a turne i'th Gallery.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Miſtris Lucy be tender-hearted to theſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They are only fit for your compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: They are worth your acquaintance, Ma|ſter Newman knows 'em; have not their wits a pretty edge?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Diſmiſſe your Beagles I ſhall beat you all three elſe, and monſtrouſly, indeed I ſhall; be rul'd, and keep your wits warme, I ſhall ſling out like winter.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thank you ſir and you be in earneſt; I
proteſt Major, and Minor, the man's in wrath, away.
How now Iames.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I am glad I ha found you ſir, your mother's come to town, ſhe rode behind me.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Not too loud, where is ſhe? I would not have it known till ſhe have other cloaths, and bet|ter breeding.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: She's at your Lodging ſir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Miſtris Ʋoluble, my mother's come by directions, mum, and make haſte; ſweet Miſtris Lucy, I beſeech you take it not unkindly if I de|part.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: By no means noble ſir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: This is my man that has brought me newes out of the Country forſooth.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: None of your Tenants dead I hope?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Some are Coppyholders, and I hope you wiſh me no harme, but I vow 'tis not my fault that I muſt take my leave ſo abruptly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You have a cheerefull licence ſir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: As I hope to make new Leaſes, and ſell a hundred Acres of wood this Terme, I am very ſorry, but I will waite upon you in the Evening. Noble Mr. New.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Ha, ha, that's a clinch.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I am your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Another Clinch I proteſt. Ex. Sim:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Now we have opportunity I preethee Mrs Voluble for my ſake tell him his Fortune; I have been a ſ●tor to know your deſtiny.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It will be a favour, it was in my ambition to deſire it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lady deſires your preſence in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I muſt obſerve her command, but you may ſatisfie the Gentleman in my abſence, and Mr: Newman when you know how the ſtarres have determined of you, make not me a more ſtranger.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I ſhal be onely fortunate to be yours.
Now Miſtris Ʋoluble, if you be acquainted with my ſtarres, and know what fortune they de|cree me, I ſtand full prepared; what lines are in my forehead, you obſerve ſo?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Pray let me ſee your hand.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Freely command it.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Some that doe make a trade of fortune|telling (which is beneath my practiſe) flatter mea for their baſe end of profit, Ile be plaine.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Truth loves no other habit, you pre|pare me to give you the more faith.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Tis very ſtrange, but this is moſt pro|pheticall, you are—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: In love.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: It may not prove ſo lucky, love is a ma||lanchoy buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I thinke it be. Is this all you can tell by your art?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: You would know your deſtiny.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat pleaſe my ſtarres and you?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Take this for oracle then, you will do ſomething in a melancholy humour will enda●||ger your neck.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My necke? ſhall I be hang'd? better the witch were burn'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Fare you well Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A pox a your prognoſtick, ſhe has put me
Into a ſweat, and I doe more than halfe

Beleeve ſhe is a witch, or worſe, in a melan|choly humour; muſt I doe ſomething to endanger my necke? unth? I ſhall put my ſelfe into a deſ|perate melancholy with thinking on't; I will be mercy, 'tis time to laugh and ſing, thoughts doe not vex me to a new tune, ther's no way but to a Taverne, Ile ſeeke out company.

lg.l: Love by your leave a while, and lazy folly,
Sacke is the Antidote to melancholy.

div.head: Act. III. Scaena. I.
div.stage: Enter Simpleton, Mother (in riding cloathes) Mrs. Ʋoluble, fames.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I Have obeyed you ſonne, but I ſhall never ſadge with theſe things you talke of.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Then y'are an aſſe, every childe can doe it.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I, if I had been a Gentlewoman of a child, much might ha been done.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
Alas after a little time, you wil take pride every day of your ſelfe; I wonder this wench
comes not! what? your ſonne has a care of you, and 'tis never too late to learne to be a Lady; this maide I commend to you, is a very rare dreſſer to a pinne, and will keepe your linnen with all variety of ſweet bagges and powders, that can be imagined; and for your rich gownes, ſhe will preſerve 'em with the new faſhion-ſereclothes, and make them outlaſt Egyptian bodyes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But muſt my old Miſtris be a Lady? that will be fine ifaith.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The Taylour has taken meaſure for a Lady I am ſure, and three or foure yards of Sat|tin, more than will ſerve for a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Then ſhe mun be kirſtned, and call'd Madam.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Peace and harken to my Landlady.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Beſides ſhe has the rareſt receits to de|ſtroy moathes, and ſuch a ſoveraigne medicine a|gainſt fleas, that your maides need never to ſqueak as if they were raviſh'd, peeping into their ſmocks before they go to bed.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: That will be fine.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: The weneh I tell you on, knowes how to conſume Cornes too, and for fidelity about your box of teeth, falſe haire, your glaſſe eye.—

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My Mother has two eyes of her owne, but that one ſquints.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
Then for all manner of Caudles, Aleber|ries, Poſſets, and preſerves in all kinds, and ſhould you lye in this maid will be the moſt diligent creature about warming of cloaths, and for brothes and gellies moſt excellent, and for all ſtrengthners of nature; then if any of your wo|men be to apt to conceive any thing that is ill,
ſhe hath her drinkes of retention, and expulſi|on—but Madam

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She is no Lady yet.!

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Sir I ſpeake what I foreſee, and there|fore among our ſelves, Madam agen, this maid is very diſcreet, you will know what that meanes, not troubleſom when your Ladiſhip would be private, nor ſuffer any elſe to trouble you, and beſide ſhe will never be in love, which is no ſmall matter for a waiting woman; ſhe is here already— Enter Nice. Mrs. Nice you are fortunate to be recom|mended, to attend this, (but a Gentlewoman yet.).

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: She is too fine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Hold your prating, and heare my Land|lady, have not you clothes to come home?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I ſhall think my ſtarres have been care|full of me, if I may have the happineſſe to ſhew my duty to ſo noble a Lady.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: She calls me Lady too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: They know what will become on you.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Oh that I could ſpeake ſo gainely; I am but new come out of the Country, but if you pleaſe to be as good as your word, I will doe the beſt I can, to be thankfull, as they ſay.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My mothers very raw, you muſt coddle her, you will have but a foule hand with her, doe you thinke ſhe will ever come to any good? the truth is, I am aſham'd on her, and therefore be not a knowne that ſhe is my mother, till you ha' diſciplin'd her, ſhe muſt live very privately.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: How ſhall her name, perſon and eſtate be publiſh'd? do not you meane to have her a La|dy?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By any meanes ſir, and let me be one of her Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: I have it; do you obſerve the maid I commended to her? She is a Gentlewoman al|waies bred among Ladies, and knows how to talk, and carry her ſelf, before any Knight or Lord in the Court: What, if for the more expedite way to your mothers inſtructions this wench ſhould take upon her ſometime to be her Miſtris, and in her name, before ſtrangers, exerciſe ſome pride and courtſhip? 'tis a neerer way by example than precept to arive at any thing; and by obſerving her Faſhion, Garbe, and Language, your mother may be ſooner ripe for a Ladiſhip by at leaſt two months, beſide all the rules ſhe may receive from us in private.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Admirable! My mother is a towardly old woman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Old? you do not know how painting may transforme Age; and the wench is not ſo young as ſhe ſeems; howſoever this will be only to ſtran|gers, and you may with more reputation own her for your mother among Gallants, 'tis but ſaying ſhe was married at twelve, and you pop'd into the world before thirteen.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I will leave her to your tuition, and this Gentlewomans education.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Then 'tis thus Madam, come hither Nice.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Iames, thou ſhalt wait upon me to my Miſtris when thou haſt better cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I have a new ſuite coming up from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Ile never live in the Country agen, ſuch another clod was I when I came to London; mo|ther
you muſt be dutifull, 'tis for your own good; but do you heare Landlady, have you ſpoke the powerfull word to my Miſtris? Shall I have her from Newman?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I have read his deſtiny, and if things hit with his credulous nature, he will make himſelf uncapable of her affection; you are the next in preferment, never feare it, and leave your mother to our method and government, we will both edi|fie, and Ladifie her.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: With all my heart: buoy Lady mother.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: If pleaſe you wee'l withdraw; you muſt be ſecret Iames. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Manly (in Leiſters habit) the two Ieerers meet him.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer:
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: The Ghoſt of Leiſter?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.l: Thus I have ſeen him painted,

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: A proper fellow?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It is not dark enough; how they gape at me?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Let's make ſport with him, he ſhews admirably by twilight, he has not travelled far ſure; ſuch a ſhape would get money in Barthol|mew Faire.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Are you a high German ſir?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis a Fencer; did you not heare of a Swiſſe that came over to be beaten at eight ſeverall weapons?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p:
By your favor ſir, no, 'tis no high Ger|man, thoſe breeches are not worne in Switzer|land,
there is ſomething of the codpiece—

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: 'Tis not His Majeſties Operatour for the Teeth, that hangs about Fleet-bridge.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: He's not ſo hanſome.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Were not you one of the brothers that guarded the Dyall at Bow Church, and us'd to put Cheapſide in mind of their quarters?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: No, he wants a Pollaxe; do you think he came not off ſome Conduit?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: I am ſure he came not off o'th' ſaltſeller, He is a ſize too tall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Theſe rogues will draw a Regiment of Prentices about me preſently, and then ſhall I be apprehended for ſome ſea monſter, and thrown into the Thames at the next Staires, to ſhew their worſhips how well I can ſwim—have you any thing to ſay to me?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: 'Tis Engliſh that he ſpeaks, he is one of us.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am one that will venture to beat you both in the ſame language, if you leave me not the ſooner.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: 'Tis ſome that skulkes in this diſguiſe for debt; we'l ſay we are Officers, and pretend to arreſt him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay then have at you bandogs—
sp.stage: Enter Newman, and Gentlemen, (their ſwords drawn.)
sp.p: A reskue?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Down with the Bayliffes, arreſt a Gentle|man in the Kings high way— Ex. Manly

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: So, ſo, he is eſcap'd. Ex. Gent.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
You curſed tadpoles, cannot a Gentle|man
walk i'th' ſtreets, but ſuch Tenterhookes muſt catch him by the cloak?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Noble Maſter Newman, we are your ſervants; do not you know us? we are no offi|cers.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Ha? If my opticks erre not, I have read
Each myſtick line within your brows,

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Have our skins cut into meaſures.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To the Taverne with me.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: We will be drunke together.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: You ſhall command us..

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: At my new Taverne where the wine ſhal flow as at a Coronation; fifty Fiddles, and a noiſe of Trumpets come along with me; you two ſhall ſend your tickets out for wenches.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Of all complexions, and degrees, from the Madam Alamode, to the humble Waſtco|teere. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I beſeech you Mrs Lucy make not me the Author, I affect Mr Newman, but this I receiv'd from good intelligence.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I am miſerable; I did not think his nature could degenerate into ſo wild a change, it is ſome witchcraft, I muſt grieve for him though I dare not ſhew it.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.p: Ther is a report, I would be loath you ſhould name me in't, but they confidently ſay; I dare not juſtifie upon my knowledge, that he has kild—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Good heaven defend; then I am more un|done.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Nay, theſe are the fruits of wine and ſur|fets; I did not ſee him bleed, but I heard it from a man of quality, and one that had been Colle|ctor in the Pariſh, who told me for certaine that Mr Newman did kill him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Whom? my afflicted heart.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: It was an Oſſicer that was ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: The more unpardonable.—VVhere?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: In the Pariſh of Alhallowes Barking, the Bell man never dawnd ſince, comming drunk out of a Taverne at twelve—he made no more adoe—there was not ſuch another dog within the VVals; it waited upon the foreſaid Bell-man a nights in His Majeſties ſervice, to waken the Pa|riſh, and all day was hir'd out by a Blind-man, that beg'd, with a Bell about his neck.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is that all the murder he has committed?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: All? you do not conſider the blind Begger that's undon by't, or who ſhall carry the Lanthorne at midnight, to light Gentlemen to the beſt Ale, and a Bawdy-houſe; but for my part Ile be no evidence, if the City will ſuffer ſuch an in|juſtice within their VValls I can be ſilent, and think.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: VVould this were all the danger, but I ſeare ſince he took up this rudeneſs and ſtrange carriage he may deſerve more ſorrow.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I love not to meddle in other mens affairs, but I know ſomething.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I prethee tell me all.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p:
The Taverne he frequents he has made his Pheater at his own charge to act intempe|rance; o're the great Roome be uſes to be drunk in, they ſay, he has built a heaven, a Players hea|ven,
and thence a Throne's let down, in which, well heated, ſucceſſively they are drawn up to the clouds to drink their Miſtris health, while the mad mortals adore their God of Grape, and gaping look like earth that's chap'd with heat, although before within three minutes they were drench'd.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Doſt know that place?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me, I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Prethee be not ſo cautious, I am his friend, and pity him; if for my ſake thou woo't but find him out, and tell him I deſire to change but a few words, truſt me, I may amply requite this ſervice.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You muſt then keep ſecret what I un|dertake, Ile do't. Be cautious to whom you ſpeake, we muſt be circumſpect. I will go off inviſible. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Monſieur Galliard, my Lady expects you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar me no like a dat reverence, me vil change a dat:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: 'Tis the French faſhion as you taught Me Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ouy, tis de French faſhion, but de French faſhion is alwaies to change, and dis reverence diſpleaſe a me very muſh, becauſe you go back, back vid your buttock, as if ſome vod take you by dat, to vat me vil give a no name.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Monſieur Galliard my Ladie will be here preſentlie.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs Lucie.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Dat de reverence is no good of de man, me muſt change dat too; by me trot me doubt dat dis great buſineſs vil almoſt break a my braine,
dis great varke, and before a maske of de King and de Queene, me can eate a no meate, no drinke, no ſleepe, and me growe ſo very a leane, vid de contemplation, a ſo much, by my trot de privy counſell is no ſo much troubled as me be vid dis, oh, le Diable! deirs is noting, dey ſit all the vile dey doe deir buſines, me biſſey bo'te head, and de foot cap a pie, in de french tune, and dat is great matre begar.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You eſteeme it highly Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me tell you, and me tell you no tale, tis great matre to make a de Lor, to make a de Lady, to make a de Gentleman, to make a de Gentil|voman, and de autre man to dance, and to make a de good reverence, for begar dat vil make a de King, de great kin in de varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How can that be Sir?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me tell you, ven dey are ſo biſſey, to learne a de dance, dey vil never tinke of de Re|bellion, and den de reverence is obedience to Monarchy, and begar obedience is ale de ting in de varke.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: I'le ſweare your ſtate affaires ly in your foot, and you are wifer there, than ſome heads are, and may be a preſident for after ages; but what muſick would you governe the people by?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar by de beſt french fidles can be got?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: What thinke you of an Iriſh harpe, a ſtate organ, or a paſtionate voyce to a lovers lute?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Des dull tings make a de men melancho|lique, and den dey tinke on de Devill, and de
treaſon, and do any ting dat is no good, but be|gar des french fidles doe fidle all deis tings out of deir head, vid ſuch a Jearke, as ma foy make a dem ſo phantaſticall, and make a dem as good ſubject, as any is in de France begar.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I muſt waite upon my Mother.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She will be here immmediately.—
She is not right yet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Here be one of my coliers, Mounſieur Sim|platon, ſay you no dat de french fidle make a de brave government in de varle?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I ſay any thing becomes a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Obſerve you dat? he have been but two are mont and he ſay any thing, dat is very brave? he have de grand underſtanding in de foot; tell a me, ven you heare a de little fidell, vat is your tinke? is your head no free from de treaſon, and plot of de rebell, as your leg? begar you no ſtand upon de ground for Joy of de Coran, de Cerebran, de Marquiſs, de Mountague, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: My Lady.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me be your humble ſervant Madam, and ſtay one two tre houre.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am now ready for you Mounſieur, come Lucy the practiſe of the laſt he taught us.

div.stage: Lady and Lucy dance, Mounſieur ſinging, and correcting them in tune.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The Gentleman you expect Sir VVilliam is come.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Madam prepare your ſelfe for mirth, 'twill be a ſight beyond the pageants.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Wee'l not be ſeen at firſt, Lucy with|draw.— Exit Lady and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What meanes this flouriſh? have you a play in hand?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.l: To bid your excellence welcome to this lodging.
Fore Jove he lookes prodigiouſly, vouchſafe
Us th' honor of your hand.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat Antick be dis?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: One of the ſupporters of the Brewers Armes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, does he take upon him to be a Prince too, and will he ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Theſe Ladyes have ambition to kiſſe your hand, and have a great deſire to know, how fares the campe at Tilbury, and pleaſe your Ex|cellencie.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis one of Arthurs Knights of the round Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: VVith his circular ſippets; would you thinke that a pigmy poiſon'd ſhould ſwell thus?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am betraid, there's no retreat with honour, I muſt be confident.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Laugh and Jeere him hanſomely.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Oh that the Major, and the Minor had been here now, they would teeze him ifaith, Mounſieur, aske that Maypole and he can dance.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Plait il Mounſieur? a la Galiard, de Goran, la Princeſſe, le Buckingham, heigh!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Put up your roſin, and your cats|guts
preſently and be gon, or I ſhall finde a grave for you in the pocket of my ſleeve, and this ſhal be your winding ſheet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me no play dat leſſon, pocket de ſleeve, dat is no tune de France, poket, le grand pock:— (Manly offers to ſtrike him) pardonne moy Mounſieur: me put up my fidell and be gon, adieu Madam, Serviteur gentilhomes; pocket de ſleeve? Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But I muſt not ſeeme angry, Lady, my buſineſſe is to you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Buſineſſe to me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am bold to preſent a ſute to you, I confeſſe it was not made by a French Tailor, I can make a leg and kiſſe my hand too after the faſhion of my cloaths, this ſerv'd in thoſe honeſt dayes, when Knights were Gentlemen, and pro|per men tooke the walls of dwarfes; here's a belly peece, that lookes like armour, with what come|lineſſe may a man unbutton his dublet, when he ſeemes to take the wall to make urine? your ſleeve ſo neere your noſe, with a handkerchiefe, which I take out thus with a grace, after Emuncti|on, I put up agen, with the corianders hanging out, Geometricall breeches in ſeverall ſliſes, in which a man is not aſham'd of his thighes, nor hides his bow leggs, which at the bottome ſur|rounded with points make him look like a rough|ſooted Pigeon, theſe things were worne when men of honor flouriſh'd, that tam'd the wealth of Spaine, ſet up the States, help'd the French King, and brought Rebellion to reaſon Gentle|men.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: So they doe now.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Peace pepper corne; and all this at leſſe charge than a maſque comes to now, with the rare and new invention of hobbiehorſes; which of our two habits (be you Lady, but the indifferent Judge, and ſquint not,) is the more grave and manly, his leane upper chinne, or this goodly promontory? my Trunkes with a round walke pav'd with gold and ſilver, or your trouſes, cut cloſe to your dock, and drawne on with a ſcrew? in which if you venture but halfe a crowne, lookes like a poltiſſe, or a ſwelling in the groine; your habit is phantaſticall as the time, you ſquirt into your dublet, which you weare ſo careleſſe as you had not button'd it ſince you came from a baw|dy houſe, where men of this garbe, coming from the ſtewes, march with that gravity as they came from a conventicle, ſo ſoherly they would carry it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I ſee whoring was equall in all times, onely the carrying of it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why that's all?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But ſurely I doe wonder, how my Grandfather could kiſſe my Grandmother, or embrace in that ſtrange apparell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They made a ſhift Knight, or elſe your wiſe worſhip had not been here; but that I want ſo much beard, I could ſhew how your Grandfa|ther ſtroak'd his three or foure handfull of haire, to the terrour no doubt of the ſtanders by, and could ſtab I warrant you, with his two handed beard then, as well as you with your dagger beard now. It was never a good time ſince theſe cloaths went out of faſhion; oh, thoſe honourable dayes and perſons!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: I pray inlarge your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To have ſeene but a St. Georges feaſt then.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Why, what difference ſir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: When they were inſtall'd, to ſee the twenty mile to Windſor ſtrow'd with blew|coates, feathers and cognizances, as they do coun|try townes with boughes, and flowers for Princes Entries, and not to go privately in a coach, with a page and a barber to cut off charges.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How doe you like this Gentleman, Is't not a pretty humour?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then you ſhould have the beſt knight of the Countrey, with the ragged ſtaffe on their ſleeves.

lg.l: The Beare, the Boare, and Talbot with his tuskiſh white,
Oh ſo ſore that he would bite,
The Talbot with his Tuskiſh white
Soudledum Soudledum;
The Talbot with his Tuskiſh white Soudledum, bell.
The Talbott with his Tuskiſh white
Oh ſo ſore that he would bite
Orebecke ſoudledum, ſing orum bell.

sp.p: Every Knight had his hundreds, and theſe would take up all the Tavernes in the Towne, be druoke to the honour of their Lords, and rather than not pay their reckoning, pawne their chains, though they pawn'd ſomething for them the night before, and ſuch merry catches then, as

lg.l: The Hart loves the high wood,
The Hare loves the hill,
The Knight lov'd his bright ſword,
And the Lady lov'd her will.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So the Ladies do ſtill.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It may be ſo, but for your Knights bright Sword 'tis at pawn, or at home in his Armory; then we had, God bleſſe the Duke of Norfolke, there was a jeaſt, and another Song.

lg.l: The great Choe bent,
The little Choe bent,
Sir Piercy leigh under the line;
God bleſſe the good Earle of Shrewsbury
For he's a good friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: He's very confident.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Alas, he is compel'd to't.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How do you like this Mrs Lucy, is he not a pretty ill-favour'd Gentleman in this habit?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: He ſings rarely.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: No queſtion he can dance too, in that diſguiſe he lookes like famous Cardell the dancing. Maſter in Queen Elizabeths time, I have ſeen his Picture.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And he with your Worſhips favour, was held a wiſe man, and for his gravity he might have been Treaſurer, he went with that ſetled and ſolid Pian-piano.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p:
And when he danc'd a meaſure, you ſhould have had him with his Rapier, ſhort Cloak,
his black Cap, and his white Feather, his ſingle and double, both backward and forward, with that excellencie—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And now he muſt be in Cuerpo, or like a fellow on the ropes, or a Tumbler when he ſhoots his body through a hoop; there was muſick then, and a Heaven and Earth, beyond your braules, or your Mountague, with a la, la, la, like a Bachana|lian dancing the Spaniſh Moriſce, with knackers at his fingers.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: It muſt needs be a rare ſight.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He plaid to himſelf on a grave Lute, or a modeſt Citterne, with a politick quill, far beyond your Geofrey fiddle, or your French kit, that looks like a broken fagot ſtick, at the biggeſt, and ſounds as if it had got the French diſeaſe, when it ſnivels out a Coranto, or ſo hoarſe with a cold, as if ſome great baſe Fiddle had filenc'd it.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: What miſery is it, the Monſieur is gone now? here had been a French Duell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But had you ſeen my Lord Loftie dance the Galliard, with ſuch capers, ſuch half capers, ſuch turns o'th toe, and above ground, you would have ſworn 'em ſound for nine Generations, and for Lavaltoes, La, la, la, &c. and then the Lady.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How did he uſe her?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: With wonderfull skill, he put his right arme about her, and took her leſt hand in his, and then he did ſo touze her with his right thigh and legg, and liſt her up ſo high, and ſo faſt, and ſo round—

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: As what I pray, be curteous.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Marry as ſoon as he had ended his dance ſhe would lye down as dead as a ſwing'd chicken,
with the head under the wing, ſo diſſie was ſhe, and ſo out of breath; and all theſe wonders were extant Knight when this old Cap was new.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Is not this very fine ſport Madam?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, y'are welcome; pray excuſe me, if being prepar'd for ſome folly, your garbe and per|ſon ſeem'd at firſt ridiculous; you have chang'd my opinion, and there wants but ſuch a noble lea|der to reduce, and make this habit faſhionable; it ſhews a proper man, and if I were worthy to ad|viſe, or could lay an obligation upon you, I ſhould take it for an honour if you would often viſit me in theſe ornaments, I like 'em infinitely, and the Wearer ſhall be ever welcome; pleaſe you wee'l walk and talk a turn in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You too much grace me Madam.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.l: I have wound my ſelf into a pretty buſineſs,

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: In my judgment 'tis an indifferent pret|ty fellow, but that his cloaths are out of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: They are moſt becomming; I do not like your new phantaſticall ſhapes, that transforme a man from his maſculine aſpect; you appear to me like a Jackanaps; there's a waſte, and a Long lane cut cloſe to your hanches. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Hum! ſhe takes after the old one, I will try and ſhift my ſelf, if the mother be taken with the habit in Qu. Elizabeths daies, why may not the daughter affect that in K. Jameſes, and ſo the humor run in a bloud? I am reſolv'd; ſhe loves ſing|ing too, I am furniſh' with Ballads, o'my conſci|ence
this will do't; Ile fit her with a faſhion, and about it preſently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: They are here agen, and laugh at me: How familiar the Turtles are?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Wee'l taſte ſome aire i'th' garden, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: So, ſo, if I did love this widow for her ſelf, what a caſe were I in? but I muſt not ſit down thus, and ſomething muſt be thought on for my honour. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. IIII. Scaene I.
div.stage: Enter Miſtris Voluble, and Nice, (having a Jewell.)

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: SO, ſo, thou doſt carry it excellently, it ſpreads like a Proclamation, what a rich widdow lies at my houſe, her wealth, and wit, muſt be exercis'd.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: She muſt not appeare to be herſelf yet but in private, and the Chiauſe her Son has be|ſtow'd this Jewell upon me for expedition, for he dares not yet acknowledge her; ſhe wonders at her||ſelf now ſhe is painted, & ſweares in her conſcience ſhe looks by her glaſs like one of foure and twenty, and ſimpers, and licks her leatherne lips as ſhe had eaten Marmalade.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir William has heard of her, and (upon ſome affront, as I conjecture receiv'd from my Lady) has writ to me, and articled already to diſpoſe her affections, I expect him every minute.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: He will diſcover us.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: He ſhall never ſee thee act her part.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Do you thinke he can affect her?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Courtiers do not marry into the City for love, and this Farmers wife has wealth enough to Enter Simpleton, and James, (with his cloaths.) buy a Ladiſhip; here's the gull, away and be dili|gent. Exit Nice.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: They'l fit you as well as my ſelf for whom they were made in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How now ſir, preparing for a race?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Is no body elſe with you? Do not en|quire what ſtratagem is in hand, there be more waies to catch a Miſtreſſes heart; how does my mother?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: She is pretty apt for one of her yeares: I can tell you news, there is a Knight about her already.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She ſhall have him.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not with your favour if a greater perſon Interpoſe, I have ſo much care of her honour, now ſhe is my charge.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Miſtris Voluble, here's a Footman, lac'd all over, enquires for you, he ſerves a French Lord, he ſaies he muſt needs ſpeak with you, he has a letter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What if this Lord come hither for the ſame purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Tis too much happineſſe; Ile not be
ſeen thus, nor let my Mother appeare in her roughcaſt, uſe the Footman kindly, if his meſ|ſage concerne us, away— Exit Ʋol.
And will this Faſhion become me, doſt thinke? I prethee tell me ſome old ſtories in to'ther raigne, thou canſt talke and make me ready too.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Ah ſir, I knew a time, when two and twen|yeares was but a merry Chriſtmas, nothing but Ambaſſadors, Maſques, Playes, Entertainements, Hawking, Hunting, Winter and Summer, New-Market and Roiſton mourne now, ha! had you ſeen the Court fox'd upon Gouries night, and the Gunpouder treaſon began then; oh we had rare ſport, and then every body was knighted, they hardly leſt a Gentleman in thoſe dayes; and afterward they got a tricke of making Lords.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I know not that, but they hardly left a Knight, man, woman, and childe were made right honourable.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Right honourable, right worſhipfull, and well beloved, I have heard that in the Coun|tr●y.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But the faſhion of welbeloved is left off, for we doe not now love one another.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But had you no misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Faith Sir, a rainy day was the worſt, and that had but made the ground more ſoluble the next day for hunting.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: No complaints James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
Oh yes ſir! I hard a Gentleman complaine mightily that he had loſt the higheſt flying taſſell gentle, that ever was ſeene, another that he had
prick'd his grey Nag, that was an excellent buck|hunter; a third, that he had fretiſh'd his beſt hound, Beauty, and that Lilly was kill'd at a Bay a ſtag-hunting, it had almoſt coſt the Genleman his life.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And what elſe James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By my troth ſir, a Gentleman waiter, that ſhall be nameleſſe, removing a paſty of Veniſon, ſpilt it all, on a new ſatten doublet, and ſpoiled it utterly, there was ſuch laughing, but his Maſter being gracious gave him a ſute for his doublet, I thinke it was a Knight; but the Knight market is riſen now.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I and the Lord Market too, James.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: And pleaſe your worſhip, they ſay, the Herald would not make a Gentleman now, under ten pound.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Oh yes, they'l take reaſon to my knowledge, and give the prettieſt phantaſticall armes, I have all the colours of the Rainebow in my new coate, every foole may be a Gentleman of three generations now.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I can derive my ſelfe knave three de|ſcents under your anceſters.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Then thy children may write them|ſelves knaves of blood, take that upon my Heral|dry; but had not you brave ſongs then James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
In thoſe dayes was the quinteſſence of ballads, you went to ſchoole with 'em, I remem|ber and learn'd no other bookes, I ſhall never for|get the Lord of Lornes ſonne in Scotland and the falſe ſteward, to the tune of greene ſleeves, thoſe were the dayes indeed, oh there was then ſuch a company for dancing ſinging and fooling, I doe
not meane the wits, for ſooling is another thing cleare from it; It does ſo bravely in company, when there is a great many that care not for wit, and pleaſes better than all the wit in the world; and then there was ſuch brave jeaſts, at the death of a Stag, and Buck; to throw blood up and downe, upon folkes faces; the very Footn en and Pages underſtood thoſe Jeaſts then; there was a time; and the Landerers were as well Employed in a progreſſe then as now, and the Surgeons got as much by 'em too; oh, I ſhall never forget thoſe times.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: So, ſo, how doe I looke in this transfor|mation? will any body know me doſt thinke? Miſtris Lucy, ſhall have the firſt ſight of my ſhape; ſome body is gone into the dining roome, let us out at the backe doore James. Exeunt.

div.stage: (Enter Nice. (dreſsing the Mother, painted) (at another Doore) Mrs. Ʋoluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis well done Nice to be carefull about your Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I am giving her ſome inſtructions about dreſſing, and was ſaying, ſhe muſt not goe above once to court in black, it would be very ſcanda|lous without intermixing colours, in her petti|cote, ſleeves, and ſtomacher, and the colours now in faſhion are blew, pincke, and incarnadine, yel|low is much worne too.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: But 'tis very materiall, what lace you wil chooſe, as ſilver and gold for blew, (Tha●'s a court maxime) and plaine ſilver for incarnadine, ſingle or mixt will ſerve for pincke colour.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I ſhall never remember all this.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: It is your Gentlewomans duty to remem|ber.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Let me alone Madam. When you will keepe houſe, a long handkercheife, or a round one with a quaife tied under your chin, and a lit|tle haire curl'd, with a black taffa ta hood, or white ſarfenet.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: When you pretend to have a cold, you muſt ſhew no haire, but weare a forehead cloth, with a pinner over that, theſe cloathes are much worne by old Ladyes, with which they binde downe a peece of ſea recloth upon their forehead, to keepe wrinckles in obedience. How is her haire?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: That little that ſhe has is crazie.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: She has enough to curle, and you have the diſcretion to know what proportion is to be leſt out, according to the latitude of her face; and to be curl'd with pinnes and orrice pouder, which will neither hurt nor breake it, and then in the Morning to let the combe paſſe through it once, and open it, between a curle and a freeze, and draw up ſome of the curles with a bodkin within the other haire.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: My haire will never indure all this.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: You muſt endure more, if you meane to be a Lady of faſhion, and attractive; where be the pendants?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Muſt ſhe not weare a Feather?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Not without a diamond bodkin; have you no Jewels?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Yes, In the knot of my handker|chiefe.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Oh fie, you muſt buy a Cabinet. What's here? a Toad ſtone, two Turkies, ſixe thumb|rings, three Aldermens ſeales, five Gemmals, and foure Deaths-heads; theſe are Alehouſe orna|ments—Yet theſe Diamonds are tollerable, and theſe Pearles will make a half Chaine.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Would ſhe were hangd in the fellow, con|dition we had the reſt.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: They muſt be changd, but Nice may weare theſe til you get new, they will ſerve to practice in. (Knock within.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: There's a Coach at doore.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Ile pawne my ability the French Lord, 'tis about the time I gave directions to his Foot|man; for his entertainment, you muſt take upon you the rich widdow, and be you carefull to ob|ſerve Mrs Nices Language, garbe, and behaviour, to men of his quality; your Rings and Jewels up|on her will credit the cauſe, and perſon he comes to viſit, which is your ſelf, but under a vaile. Ile prepare his Lordſhip. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: This is all for your inſtruction; theſe rings fit me excellent well, and hereaſter you may take pride upon you by my example.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall learne in time; but I ſhall be more than a Lady if I marry with a Lord.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Alas, I am but the Lady in the Play.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now you put me in mind, I have ſeen pret|ty harlotry Ladies in a Country Play, ſo proud, and ſo knaviſh, one would have ſworn they had been women indeed.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p:
Hee's here, you muſt be modeſt, and ob|ſerve your diſtance now; Is this the Lord? He
looks like an over-grown Monkey.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: What pretty fooliſh things ſome of theſe young Lords are?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is bountifull; that is ſhe whom fame hath delivered to you; your honour may advance.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar dis riſh viddow looke young as my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Vol
sp.p: If my eyes be not in a miſt this is the French Dancer.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat is your name?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He means to catechiſe her.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I ſhall be happy if your Lordſhip pleaſe to own me by the title of your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You muſt learne to complement thus—'Tis Galliard ſure.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: She kiſſe very vel begar, ſhe have de Ala|mode touch of de lip ma foy; can you dance Madam?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I am now confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Will he kiſſe me too?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman that attends me for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dat is a de reverence for de divel, ſhe look like a de wihch Madam, but me tell you Ma|dam, for me love you very muſh in the little time, as any man in de varle; me be French Lor, and me have lodging in de autre ſtreet, Duke de Me|morency my kinſman, and two tre hundred great Lors have loſe deir head in France begar for no matre, and me flye to Englan to ſave a me neck by me trot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Were you guilty of any treaſon?

sp.speaker: Gal
sp.p: No more begar than your little ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: What is your eſtate?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar very grand eſtate in Orleance, me have two tre Lettre from de Cardinall, and he write a me, dat de King ſend for me to kiſs his hand: Now as me vas in de reſolution to take a de ſhip for France, me heare of you Madam in de Strand, and me very glad to marry you before me go preſently.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is very briefe, but I find not my ſelf enclin'd to croſſe the Seas.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: The Sea, mary ſhield, Ile not ſee the ſalt water for any Lord in Chriſtendome, I, Ile rather be no Lady.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Who, how now inſolence, how dare you interpoſe?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Will you be ridiculous, and betray your ſelf now?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you have de Gypſey complexion, and looke like de ſign of-de Robin Hood and maid a Marian.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Robin Hood in thy face, does he maid a Marian me?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: She is not worth your Lordſhips paſſion, I ſhall teach you better manners.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you ſhall have muſh need of dat.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My Lord, you did aske me if I could dance.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The wench has found him.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dere is noting in de varle for de Lady, like a de underſtanding in de foot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I cannot praiſe my own ability, but I ad|mire the excellency of other Ladies, and ſhould be fortunate to meet with ſome Maſter in thafa|culty, that would Inſtruct, and exerciſe me in private.

sp.speaker: Gal.
