sp.p: Me love you de bettre for da●, begar no body exerciſe you in private but my ſelf, me teach you Alamode de Court dance, hold up your litel fingre you command a my foot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is too humble, it is an office would become one that is mercenary; I af|fect dancing infinitely, oh that we had but ſome muſick here; la, la, ra. (She ſings, Gal. draws out his Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: ●is comming out.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: What's that a bedſtaffe?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: It is a French pocket-piſtoll.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Will he ſhoot it oft here? I could never indure a gun. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal
sp.p: Forboon, brave, ah, dat is like a de Prin|ceſs, Allez.

sp.speaker: N●
sp.p: You ſhall not be ſo publick in your graces to me; conceale your Fiddle tillſome private op|po●runity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me underſtand.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How does your Lordſhip like her? You have her in an excellent humour.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Kiſſe a me madam—hah? 'tis heaven? de Poet talke of de Nectar, begar here is it; me never drink de●vine blanke or de Claret, ſo me have but two tre drop divine from your lip—Metreſſe ſpeake a for me.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The foole is extaſied; in his worſt conditi|on he will ſerve for a husband; how he dances in a Net?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He has money, and a Trade, he will ſerve wench.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: If me get dis riſh widdow, me cozen 'em both begar.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Do you think he loves me indeed. Ex. Vol.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You no tinke madam dat me be ſo hot in love, and do burne, dat my reine a do melt, as me vere in de oven, me need a go into de river pre|ſantly to coole and vater my heart, vere is de Mi|ſtreſſe de la Maiſon? Gone? dat is vel, dere is no honor like a dat, as you take a de litel aire in my Coach.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I have not been abroad to day, but I dare truſt my ſelf with your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Oh Madam, a voſtre ſervice, now if me get a de Prieſt all is perfect.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Be all theſe Trunkes hers?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: We ha not ſtowage enough for half, ſhe is infinitely rich.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Haſt thou prepar'd her?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: I find her very apt, 'tis her only ambition to be a Lady, a French Lord has her in chaſe, but I have delivered your character, and what privi|ledge ſhe may have by charter of her Knight.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: I long to ſee her, is ſhe handſome?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What ſhe wants in beauty and breeding, ſhe has in eſtate Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: That, that's enough, I can have beauty in other places, and will exceed what I conditi|on'd for, if I proſper. I will have this Widdow in ſpight.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: To ſpight the Lady Beaufield, and her Magog that affronted me; I would loſe no opor|tunity, a widdow muſt be taken in the pick; ſay I am come and commend me to the heavens, Ile make all good.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: To the heavens? will you dye before her?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: For that we muſt take our chance; thou ſhalt be ſure of a good leaſe for thy life, and deſti|ny agree upon us afterward.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Shall I direct you?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Sha't be my evening, and my morning ſtar. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You too much afflict your ſelf Miſtris Lu|cy, 'tis but ſome humour he put on to try the ſtrength of your affection.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: He is loſt; not for my ſake, but for his own I pitty him, and I am confident, if I were ſo hap|py to ſpeak with him agen, I ſhould prevaile to win him to his firſt and noble temper; my end being ſo juſt, I could diſpence with modeſty to find him out, and perfect the act of charity.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You have imployd Formoll, from whom you may expect to heare ſuch an account, as may dry up your ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I ſee Sir you preſerve your confidence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I dare be juſt in your commands, and in a ſervice you but ſmile upon, deſpiſe the cenſure of the world.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Saw you not the Knight ſince?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The ſweet hopes that he ſwallow'd, to prepare me a ridiculous object to you Madam, was gall upon his ſtomack, when he found you had mercy on my confidence; he dares not converſe with ſo unlick'd a beare, as this ſhape muſt preſent Enter Simpleton, and James. his criticall eye ſight. Whats here? one ſent to affront me?

sp.speaker: Simp.

lg.l: When Robin came to Nottingham dery, dery down,
His dinner all for to dine:
There met him fifteen ●olly Foreſters,
Were drinking Ale, and Wine, hey down.

sp.p: Madam your moſt humble ſervant; there be other men, and manners, and garbes as faſhionable in the eyes of diſcreet Ladies.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have we got Adam Bell, and Clim o'th Clough?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: We be three, good Mr William of Cloudeſly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And how, and how ſhew matters Miſtris Lucy? every mans Cap is not made of the ſame matter.

l.hi: Have you felt the wooll of Beaver?
—Have you ſmelt of the bud of the Roſe?
—Or have taſted the bag of the Bee?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, this is moſt uncivill, and your raſh|neſſe, beſide the forfeit of your own diſcretion, will lay an imputation to wound my fame; with|in my preſence, and beneath my roofe, which ſhould protect all ſtrangers, to affront a Gentle|man that viſits me—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Be bold ſir, and preſume you have my favour, you never appear'd handſome till this minute; beare up, your mirth becomes you rare|ly.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Dos't iſaith?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: What does my mother meane?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Spit o' thy hand, and clap me oth' ſhoulder Iames, the widow her ſelfe is in love with me.

lg.l: She caſt an eye on little Muſgrave
As bright as the ſummers ſunne.

sp.p: I may turne o're the Daughtet to thee.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I would I had her in an Embroiderd clout.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sure my Lady is but in jeaſt.

lg.l: Shew me ſaid he whoſe men ye be
That hunt ſo boldly here,
That without my conſent do chaſe
And kill my follow Deere.—

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: His follow Deere?

lg.l: Ere thus I will out braved be
One of us two ſhall dye,
I know thee well an Earle thou art,
Lord Percy, ſo am I.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Thou Douglas?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
This Lady has but fool'd me all this while; make much of your new Antick Madam, I can ſhift into my ſelfe agen, and if that thing were worth my anger, or my envy, beate him;
you have a pretty humour, cheriſh it, and that William of the Wiſpe, till I viſit you agen.— Exit

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The Gentleman is jealous.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I proteſt Madam if it had hot been not your ſake, and that it had been pitty to have ſpilt any blood, in your Dining roome, I would ha done ſomething

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: In his breeches.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But I ſhall report your nobleneſſe a|broad.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Doe not play the foole to much, I am out of the humour to laugh at you; he cannot leave me thus.— Exit Beau.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: This was no tricke to catch the old one.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How came you into this habit Simpleton?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By reading Ovids Metamorphoſis, and to ſhew the variety of my wit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you hold your feet toge|ther,—now you put me mind of a Smiths bel|lowes, your body is not all of a peece ſure, but ſeverall limbes thruſt into ſeverall pudding bags, you would ſhew terrible to the crowes in a wheat field, you are no living creature.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Perſwade me to that, am I not ſenſible?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He that does that cure upon you, will de|ſerve a chronicle; ſo deſiring you would take home your flaile there, for here is like to be no thraſhing worke, I commit you to the Barne, where like another Orpheus, you will draw the horſe, and ſheepe, to the melody of your voyce, and raviſh all the Cowes in the Countrey, to heare you ſing Packingtons pound.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: She has made a coxcombe on you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p:
Hum? I wo'not out o'the pit for all this, I
have another deviſe, and thou ſhalt aſſiſt me, if that faile, I'le dye a bachelor, and make thee my heire.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I ſhall but pray for your death ſir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Back agen, back agen quoth the Pindar,
The wrong way have you go●, &c.

div.stage: A Table, Stooles, Bottles of wine, and Glaſſes, ſet out by two Drawers.—then Enter Newman, the two Jeerers, Wenches, Muſitians.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So, ſo, I'le dance no more, a ſong, lets have a ſong now.

sp.speaker: 1 Wen.
sp.p: Take heed of the old ballads, ecclip|ed, Like Hermit poore, eyes hide my love, or Panae in the brazen Tower.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: Or the lamentable complaint of Ariad|ne, and Theſeus, and the more lamentable for being ſo long.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Doe you heare Madam vertue, Lady modeſty cannot you play your part?

sp.speaker: 1 Je.
sp.p: Not upon the violin.

sp.speaker: 2 Je.
sp.p: They are both for the Gambo.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You ſhall play the part of my Miſtris, you muſt be witty then, and extreame coy and ſcurvy, in your anſwers; go behind that hanging, I will ſuppoſe it your chamber; now Boy the Song I made to the window, while I muſtle my ſelfe with the fidlers, to bid my Miſtriſſe good morrow in the ſtreet, obſerve the conjuration.

lg.l: I conjure thee, I conjure thee, by thy skin that is ſo faire,
Thy dainty curled haire,
And thy favour and thy grace,
With the patches on thy face,
And thy hand that doth invite
The cold, dulleſt appetite,
—Appeare appeare,
Ʋpon theſe termes I doe invite thee,
And if thou com'ſt I will delight thee.
If not ſo, I doe not care,
Though thy breaſts be ne're ſo bare,
Roſes rich, with shooe that's white,
Or thy Venus beſt delight,
If not touch thy ſofter skin
What care I for thee a pin,
Appeare appeare.
For to heare, and not to ſee
Is a dull flat hiſtory,
And to ſee and not to touch
If you thinke the laſt too much,
Know all woman's but one ioy
If we men not them enjoy,
Appeare appeare.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: She's not awake, play a ratling tune that may ſtartle her; where's this whore? ha!—

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: She's gone.

sp.speaker: 2 Jer.
sp.p: Vaniſh'd? ſo he might have ſung a|way his lungs.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It may be, ſhe is retir'd, for you know what Lady; come let us drinke.

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.p:
Was your Muſe at all this expence
to the fidles? do you write to no other company ſir?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Till they have my liveries; Ile maintaine 'em in ſongs, wind up your voyce agen▪

lg.l: Thine eyes to me like ſunnes appeare
Or brighter ſtarres their light;
Which makes it ſummer all the yeare,
Or elſe a day of night:
But truely I doe thinke they are
But eyes, and neither ſunne nor ſtarre.
Thy brow is as the milky way,
Whereon the gods might trace:
Thy lips Ambroſia I dare ſay
Or Nectar of thy face:
But to ſpeake truely I doe vowe
They are but womens lips and browe.
Thy checke it is a mingled bath
Of Lillyes and of Roſes;
But here there's no man power hath
To gather loves freſh poſies:
Beleeve it here the flowers that bud
Are but a womans fleſh and blood.
Thy noſe a promontory faire,
Thy necke a necke of land;
At natures gifts that are ſo rare
All men amaz'd doe ſtand:
But to the cleerer judgement thoſe
Are but a womans necke and noſe.
For foure lines in paſſion I can dye
As is the lovers guiſe,
And dabble too in Poetry
Whilſt love poſſeſt, then wiſe
As greateſt States-men, or as thoſe
That know love beſt, yet live in Proſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: The pure ſpirit of Sack in't.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: The wits Elixar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: No jeering Gentlemen, I ſhall grow loud and break the peace.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: Theſe Gentlemen are for nothing but ſong and drink, I ſee no market all this while; Ile get me hence too; if pleaſe you, Ile ſee if I can find out my ſiſter. Ex. 2 Jeer.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's but one ſtoole in the counting houſe, and Lady you ſhall ſtay till ſhe returne; Gentlemen there's no life in you; I cannot do this roring and whoring handſomely; little thinks Lucy what Comrades I have got.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: I have a pretious confidence in you Gen|tlemen, to truſt my ſingle modeſty amongſt ſo many.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat would you give to be raviſh'd now? thou haſt an excellent complexion for't.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: Raviſh'd? preſerve the Gentlemans deare wits Sack I beſeech thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You would not loſe by it if he raviſh you.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: another Song, and direct your voice to this Lady.

lg.l: I'de have her merry, laugh, and ſmiles
And then look grave and ſad:
In every humour but a while,
Make love as 'tis, that's made
I'de have your dreſſe of ſever all ſhapes,
Like Proteus carv'd, not he,
In humour a ſhe coy Jackanapes
Then a grave Monkey be.
Diſcourſe of all that comes to ſence,
But ſpeak none, yet ſtill ſpeak,
No matter here is no offence,
But to ſpeake matter weak.
With thy ſoft voice ſing me aſleep,
Then ſtartle me awake,
With Loves notes-paſsion make me weep,
Then merry for thy ſake.

sp.speaker: Jeer. Mi.
sp.p: A diſcovery?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What new-found Land?

sp.speaker: Jeer. Mi.
sp.p: The Pigeon that left us hath been in another roome with Mr Formall my Lady Beau|fields Gentleman Uſher, there he ſits like the picture of a Harry Soveraigne in a chaire, while ſhe is picking on's pocket.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Fetch him, and his Fairy hither, but for his Mrs ſake uſher him with loud muſick. Ex. Jeer.
Wee'l have ſome ſport. (Flowriſh.

div.stage: Enter the two Jeerers, and Formall.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Where's the wench?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: The wench has made an eſcape, ſhe had a glimpſe before and ſuſpected me, but here's the wicked Elder.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What ſaies my wiſe▪ Lu●ullus?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sir, my buſineſs was to you, though I met a Remera that is already ſunke, I was ſent by a Gentlewoman, but no body muſt know it.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: We heare no buſineſs till he have wound up a bottle, and then he ſhall have audience.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: That's but your fee for entrance, your garniſh only; come ſir there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I hope you will conceale it Gentlemen.

lg.l: Why then let us drinke,
Away skurvy thinke,
And do't till we winke;
Which is juſt to be
So drunke not to ſee.
Firſt Maudlin to weep,
Then after to ſleep;
Why they let us drinke,
And do't till we winke,
Away skurvy' thinke.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: VVhar will become of me? would you and I Lady were in a back roome.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So now ſpeak my Lord Embaſſador, I know your ſoveraign Lady greets us well.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Alas ſir, my Lady does not know of my comming; I would ſpeak with you from one that ſhall be nameleſs, who thinks you are a debauch'd Gentleman, under the Roſe, and deſires to talk with you when you are ſober: I would be loath to diſgrace you before this good company, neither was I willing to tell her what I heard about your drinking and whoring.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To the point.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: I, I, to the point.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The principall matter then, and indeed my whole employment at this time to you is—

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: VVhat in the name of circumſpection?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me ſir, filence is a vertue; but if you knew who ſent me—

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: He would make a coſtive Stateſman.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: It is ſufficient one deſires to ſpeak with you, I name no time, nor perſon, I know my office; Miſtris Lucy is not to be named at all times.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Miſtris Lucie, I am her ſervant; come drink this narrow ſea to her health, you muſt be drunk inſallibly, Ile give a reaſon; I ſweare by Muſcadell That I do love her well; come yee Mermaids—

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ile do you reaſon then; but is this Muſ|cadell? Mr Newman has ſworne; for my own part, Gentlemen, I deſire it ſhould go no further.

lg.l: I ſweare by Muſcadell
That I do love thee well,
And more than I can tell.
By the White, Claret, and Sack
I do love thy Black, black, black,
I do love thy black, black, black.
No Goddeſſe 'mongſt them all
So ſlender, and ſo tall,
And gratefull too with all,
Which makes my ſmews to crack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
So lovely, and ſo faire,
Though ſhaddow'd with thy haire,
So nimble, juſt like aire;
All theſe ſet me on loves wrack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
Thy kind and cunning eye,
When firſt it did eſpy,
Our love it did deſcry,
Dumbe ſpeaking, what d'you lack?
Mine anſwer'd, thy black, black,
Thy dainty black, black, blacke.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Now give Mr Formall his cup.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I have had the narrow ſea, I cannot drink an Ocean.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: His t'other cup; you had my wench as I remember, and Ile preſcribe you a pennance; there's another whore for you, drink to her and ſhee ſhall pledge.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, and ſet thy foor to mine.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You may truſt your ſingle modeſty with him.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: For my own part, I had rather do things privately; come kiſſe me firſt—here's to thee, my fleſh tingles—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A word with you two Squiers.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Any thing for a ſhelter, I foreſee a ſtorm; and what is one Cat among ſo many Maſtives?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You are melancholly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You lye, you that ſay nothing lye, if you be of his opinion.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Me thinks we are very merry.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: We are exceeding merry.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Have you diſcharg'd your Culvering? where's the paraquito?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I drunke it off.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: She is vaniſh'd too.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
Then we are our ſelves, and make me
your example; you know your Province Sirra, make ready for an Angell, ſing the deſigne of ho|nour, and of fancy. Ex. boy.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: But firſt in Phanſie we will foole,
Pull off our Dublets, drinke more coole,
Our hats upon our heads not ſtay,
For each health wee'l throw them away
So Periwig, or Fringe, or Border,
The naked truth wee'l drink in order.
And to the Muſick as they play
A Phanſie Peece wee'l throw away,
Ʋntill we are drein'd, can draw no more,
And the next day all cry therefore.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Off With Formalls Doublet, off with his Doublet, throw't into the fire, that's a good phan|ſic; now he is Formall right.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I did not drink hard, for I am cold, the wench would keep me warme, ſhe's a notable fire|drake; will it pleaſe you ſir to go to the party?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Now does he betray what a Bawd he would be.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Does no body know where to get a Ser|pent with two legs that hath never a ſting?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I have a great mind to drink a health in one of my boots.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I drink no beere glaſſes, if a ſhooe will ſerve turne—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: His ſhooe, my ſcabberd, a match.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: My glove.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: His cap.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Fill brimmers, every man to his Miſtris; now do not I like this phanſie.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We ha don't.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's wooll in my ſcabbard, which is a ſpungious matter, and when I ha done (Muſick Throne deſcends I may leave my drink behind me, and that's a hanging matter, which I am principally to avoid—Do you heare the Muſick of the Spheres Gentle|men?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: From the roofe a Throne?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: This roome is mine, and cald the field of Tempe; Becauſe I woonot ſtay while (The Wench peeps from under the Table. the Plaies are done when I have a humor to be merry, and drink healths in the clouds, I built this Eliſium; and when bright Sack hath crown'd my brow, how ſoon I am made immortall, you may gueſſe.

lg.head: A Song in the Throne.
lg.l: As I ſinging now came down,
I do bring you Bacchus Crown:
From the plumpe Lord of the vine
Cluſterd grapes to make you wine,
Your ſweld Temples circling in,
Crown'd with this, and bath'd within;
Therefore your beſt wiſhes bring,
Place this Garland on your King.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is not Bacchus the beſt good fellow God on 'em all? Let me ſee, Formall ſhall be King, and he ſent to heaven preſently.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Send me to heaven? why ſhould I be ſent thither before another man?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Ret, Ret, verily Ret, here's the Fartridge under the Table.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They'l be good company, they ſhall both be immortall together, helpe Gentlemen. Boy you muſt be depos'd.

sp.speaker: VVench.
sp.p: Alas what ſhall I doe?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You ſhall to heaven Lady?

sp.speaker: VVench.
sp.p: What before my time? and whether I will or no?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It ſhall be with as much eaſe, as if it were in a Featherbed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Let us ſleepe together.

sp.speaker: VVench.
sp.p: Ah pitty a poore Gentlewoman, if you have hearts of fleſh, do not uſe me worſe than heathen Prentices.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So crowne 'm, and give to each a glaſſe of wine, for a ſcepter.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, if we muſt mount, 'tis none of our ſeeking, we are but Angells in our owne defence, for my owne part, I deſire to go thether in no better company.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Up with 'em, and preſerve your ſcepter glaſſes, doe not ſpill your blood royall.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Alas, hold there for heavens ſake, I muſt meet three Innes of court Gentlemen at the Stillyard to night, it may be out of my way 20. pound, conſider your owne caſes.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Peace gentle Queene of grapes.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Thou art a traitor too, oh!

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Doe not jog the chariot, let us take our preſerment patiently, and drinke a health to the humble mortalls, that turne up their whites to us, this is pretty high drinking.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Drunkards, divells? oh that I were up|on earth agen.—

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Is this the Gentlewomans wine, or water?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: He mounts inſenſibly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They have a heavenly time on't; you know me ſirra.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Noble Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's for your attendance.

sp.speaker: Jeer.
sp.p: What's to pay?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They ſhall pay you the reckoning in the other world, you know the back way thither; come my boyes to the departed, having paid all rites
We now returne.

sp.speaker: Jeerers.
sp.p: Like woefull Adamites.

div.head: Act. V. Scaena. I.
div.stage: Enter Simpleton, James, (little Table ſet out.)

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: IAm reſolved, ſince faire meanes can|not prevaile with Miſtris Lucy, to ſteale her away, this is the key of the back-gate o'th' garden, to the fields, be ready when I give the ſigne to hurry her into the coach, and when I have her at my Countrey-Houſe, Ile take in her maiden towne, upon my owne compoſition.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: You wo'not raviſh her.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There are twenty wayes to deale with a woman, and never raviſh her; no, I have plaid the foole too much.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I am of your opinion.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But ſhe ſhall find if I get poſſeſſion.—

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: The Coachman is a luſty fellow too, and will help to clap her abroad; the curtaines being cloſe ſhe cannot be heard, and the horſes will runne, as the devill were in the poope, for he drives like a Tamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Holla ye pamperd Jades.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: One Traitour more were not amiſſe for al that.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Thou ſaiſt right, for though ſhe be a little woman, her voyce may be too ſtrong for us.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Let us alone, mind your owne part.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Be reſolute James. —Exit Simp.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: The courſe I am in, hath brought ſome men to the Gallowes, and doe I take it for pre|vention?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: What deſperate fellow's that?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I am weary of wine and noiſe, is there no other cure for melancholly? I doe not love the cramp in my necke.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: He lookes like a Gentleman that were in debt; my friend doe you come hither to finde a tree? th'art a proper fellow, doſt want employment, for though your cloathes have a good gloſſe, they looke as they were ill lin'd, they want money.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I ſuffer that which made the old woman mend her pace fir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Doe as Ile direct thee.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Whom doe you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I ſerve my ſelfe; my Maſter is a foole; did you never heare of Simpleton?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That worſhipfull puppy?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: He knowes him. I have ſeen you before, but 'tis no matter where; I like thy countenance; can'ſt keepe counſell? walke o'this hand o'me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay a little further Miſtris Lucy, it ſeemes Mrs Ʋoluble told him no great good fortune, ſhe ſaw it in his ſtarres, for you know ſhe weares A|ſtrology at her apron ſtrings; but ſhe told me in private who ſhould be the man, your deere En|dymion.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Who I beſeech you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The object is preſented, and 'tis in vaine to oppoſe the Conſtellations, what muſt be muſt be, and there were no more Ladyes in the world, I am the man.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To ſteale her away?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: My Maſter is reſolv'd. They are here; cloſe.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: She is betraid.—

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Now.—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Help; theeves.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Stop her mouth.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Then every man take his chance.

div.stage: (He ſtrikes downe Simpleton. Lucy runs eff.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Are you ſo cunning ſir? you ſhall along with us. (They diſ|arme New.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Worried by Hedghogs!

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Are you not kill'd outright ſir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I am not certaine, be ſure you hold him faſt; to the next Juſtice; I muſt get a Surgeon. You are my rivall, I know you well enough, if I miſcarry, it ſhall coſt me a hundred pound, but Ile ha thee hang'd for't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I underſtand you perfectly Miſtris Voluble, and like your propoſition; but a word more of the widdow that is at your' houſe, ſhee is very rich you ſay?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not in underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Tis the better.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Her's all your worſhip muſt promiſe her, to be knighted, for ſhe hath a great mind to bee a Lady.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I know where a blanck lies dormant for a Baronet, it will carry more noiſe and authority on the bench too.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You have done me ſome diſcourteſie here tofore, in beleeving the complaints of Intempe|rate tongues againſt me, but you ſee my charity I deſire to live in your worſhips faire opinion 〈◊〉 a neighbour.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I will make you amends ſweet Miſtris V●||luable, y'are a vertuous Gentlewoman on my con||ſcience: but how ſhall this widdow be wrought?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
Thats done already. The truth is ſhe in|quir'd
of me, (for we women uſe to open our ſe|crets one to another) for ſome ſtayd Gentleman that was a Lawier, (becauſe ſhe has ſo great an e|ſtate, and many ſutes to follow) on whom ſhee might beſtow her ſelfe, for the ſecurity of her for|tune, and I have already prepared her, and ſuch a commendation of your perſon, and learned gra|vity, a Juſtice of Peace and Quorum, out of my private reſpects to you, without deſire or expecta|tion of any bribe or reward.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I underſtand that very well.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I know you doe.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: How much I am bound to your vertue?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The widdow has a great mind to ſee you, but I will contrive it for your honour, ſhee ſhall come hither, as to her learned Counſell.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: The invincible wit of a woman! how I honour it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There can bee no loſſe in't if you get a Chaplaine in readineſſe, widowes are taken in the opportunitie.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: A Gentleman brought to be examined, that has wounded one Maſter Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Simpleton? that's the widowes ſon.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Richard, ſend to the Curate of the Pariſh, ſay I would ſpeake with him preſently.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Alas who hurt you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My rivall Maſter Newman, Is this the ●uſtice?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
A former quarrell; if you die, I have ●aw
enough to make it murther, for your good Mo|thers ſake.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Cannot you make it manſlaughter, and let me live? for I deſire but his death.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Hee ſhall make it what you pleaſe. This Gentleman is to bee Knighted, and loves your mother above all the world, things meet as cloſe, as if they went to engender.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My Mother is worth ſix thouſand pound, if you will promiſe to make her a Lady, and doe your beſt to hang the Gentleman, you ſhall be my Father in Law, when my Landlady ſayes the word.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Sweet Miſtris Voluble, leave your friend to me, I underſtand the matter perfectly, and it ſhall goe hard, but wee will have all the Law on our ſide. Call in the offender; pleaſe you ſit; Ri|chard be ready with your Ammunition, Pen, Inke and Paper.

div.stage: Enter Surgeon, Newman, Iames, Coachman, Conſtable and officers.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: VVhat is your name ſir?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: My name is Seare.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: He is the Surgeon ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Ile teach you ●o follow your profeſſion ſirra, Ile make you an example to all Phleboto|mers; how often have you beene indited for letting of blood firra?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I underſtand you nor.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
But I underſtand you ſirra; how durſt you vi & armis, felloniouſly aſſault this noble Gentle|man in contempt of peice, and the Kings Law,
his Crowne and dignity? anſwer me ſirra to that. Ile ſeeze him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: You VVorſhip is miſtaken, I never ſee the Gentleman before, I was ſent for—

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: He is the Surgeon ſir, that is come to take meaſure of my Maſters wounds, it was that Gent|leman that let him blood.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: VVhy do they not change faces then? away you knave, and looke to the Gentleman; you ſtand idling here to ſtumble authority with a fel|lonious countenance.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Let us be for ſworne both in a tale.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, you are one that ſhould doe Juſtice; where is my poore friend? bee not ſo much de|jected, you did but reſcue me ſir from diſho|nour.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I was in a melancholly humour; 'tis come about as the wiſe woman concluded.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: VVher's Simpleton? I may accuſe him for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Take heede what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Or ſome ſuch black intent; this Gentle|man but interpos'd to ſave me from their ſurie, and with his ſword puniſh'd a bold offender by letting out ſome blood that was corrupted.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Thats not materiall; will you confeſſe you wounded Maſter Simpleton? come to the matter.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I confeſſe it ſir, but heare the reaſon.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
I will heare no reaſon, that were ſimple juſtice; take him aſide, and you may follow your
buſineſſe. Stay young Gentlewoman, I muſt exa|mine you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Shall I withdraw, and ſhut the doore?

div.stage: Exeunt all but Iuſtice and Lucie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: VVhat Juſtice ●ir, or Law is this?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: It is not Polton, Crompton, nor Fitzerhert, A Juſtice ought to have ſome diſcretion without booke, eſpecially in theſe caſes. I grant you are the root and cauſe of this misfortune.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ●ir?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Be wiſe, and underſtand me; nd being in|dued with ſuch gifts of nature, native beauty and favour, (come a little nearer) and you to abuſe your ſelfe—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Or ſuffer your ſelfe to be abuſed (come a little nearer) is not to be thankefull for thoſe ex|cellent benefits.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: VVill you tranſlate an Inſolence in others upon my guilt?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: You accuſe an honeſt Gentleman for an intent of rape; alas poore ſoule, it was pure af|fection in him, hee would have raviſhed you no doubt, with your owne conſent, the fault was your Ingratitude, (a little nearer) Seneca doth write much of Ingratitude, that I may come (a little nearer) or elſe Nero had not let him blood, (yet nearer) this Nero was a moſt wicked Tyrant, for all he could play upon a fidle, make ballads, and ſing them himſelfe, and therefore take heede of cruelty, and be gentle, he kiſſ●th her.●or, ſweet-heart Nero died a violent death.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: My Mother.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Lucy you made haſte.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Your pardon Madam.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: I underſtand ſhe is a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: In the defence of my owne vertue, and the noble Gentleman that ſuffers for his charity to me—

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.p: I came to aſſiſt you. It were an injurie to doubt your juſtice. My name is Beaufield. If my credit may be interpos'd ſecurity for New|man my daughters knowledge in the cauſe will Enter Clarke. give a moſt cleare ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Richard, call in the delinquent, this Lady has ſpoken very much to the matter, as I under|ſtand it. Has the Surgeon done yet?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: They are comming downe.

div.stage: Ent●r Surgeon, Newman, Simpleton, Iames, Conſtable, Officers.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Now ſir, how many of his wounds are mortall?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: There is not one conſiderable, the Gen|tleman is in no danger.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But have not you authority to hang him? Ile take my oath, he had an intent to kill me. My Lady and Miſtris Lucie? Iames, Ile ſtay no lon|ger, ſince I am not mortally wounded, ſneake af|ter me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My hanging ●it is over, and the witch|craft, I am now my ſelfe again, if you can pardon Enter Manley. me Madam this too great an honour to your worthleſſe ſervant.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: How now? what ſaucie fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Shee's here too. I am bold Cozen to viſit you, they ſay, ther's a Gentleman brought before you, for breach o'th' peace, I come to baile him.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: We take no forrainers; what outlandiſh thing are you, pray?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You know me ſir, my name is Manley, you ca●ld me cozen yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Luſt.
sp.p: I never ſaw you before. I know that name, and a Gentleman that ownes it, a kinſman of mine too, but he is no ſuch Brandemart. Richard, doe you know this Mahound? he calls himſelfe my cozen Manly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why in this habit?

sp.speaker: Iuſt
sp.p: Tranſmigration?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is it not ſome ſpie ●ir?

sp.speaker: Iuſt
sp.p: Conſtable take him to your charge. Ile teach you ſirra, to uſurpe a Gentlemans name; tis fello|ny ipſo facto, write his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By what ſtatute? Trigeſimo Secundo of King Phillip? I doe not Madam deſire your cer●ificate.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Y'ar● a ſtranger ſir to me, yet I dare bee engag'd for his forth comming, hee has an honeſt face.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Come hither Richard, theres halfe a peece, rub thy eyes woo't, are they open yet?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
I ſee you plainely now ●ir, y'are my Ma|ſters
cozen, 'tis Maſter Manley.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis your beſt courſe to owne me too; is it ſo long ſince you tooke bribes, ſince you divided and manumisd a crooked chambermaid that robd her Miſtris of old Gold? there was a Lancepreſa|do ſtript a hedge, when you were out of Linnen; Peuter has been left at the back-doore, when you did ſtudy Alchymie; I leave the tricke you ſhew'd the Sailors wife in your Cloſet, when you pro|mis'd a reprieve to her goodman from Wapping; I know not that you have run your wither'd mot|ley face into a prem●nire; doe not know me, why d'ee no● charge the conſtable?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: What is a Juſtice without eyes, I meane ſpectacles? 'tis he indeed, I underſtand, and ſee him perfectly; welcome, a Chaire for my Co|ſen?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So then. Madam a word with you, I'le make you know me too, ere I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: There is a matted Chamber & a Couch—More buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vere is de matre Juſtice? begar dey have put de ſheare upon me, me expect de riſh vidow, and have marry the chambermaid, ſhe confeſſe dat, Maitre Juſtice, pray take her to your ſelfe, me deſire your varrant, for Metreſſe Ʋoluble, dat ſhe bring the vidow Simplaton to marry me ſans ceremoine, dat is your commiſſi|on, or begar me complaine of you to de King.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Did you expect the rich widow Simple|ton? h●, ha! I know this trifle, my Clarke knowes her better

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Bergar Matre Juſtice, and Matre Clarke make your diviſion, dat is all you ſee.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Sir I have onely cauſe to complaine, he told me he was a French Lord, Miſtris Ʋoluble ſhall make affidavit, and courted me to be his Lady, and now we are married, he proves but a cinquepace. I look'd for thouſands per annum, and he is but one, two, three, foure, and five.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: How, did he pretend himſelfe to be a Lord? 'tis Scandalum Magnatum in the higheſt degree: and by a ſtatute quinquageſimo of the Queene, if ſhe proſecute, he is to be whip'd, and loſe his eares three ſeverall market dayes.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: How will you divide his Eares into three equall portions?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me give a de whip, and me Ioſe a mine 'ares!

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: You heare the law, if I complaine.

sp.speaker: I. Ieer.
sp.p: Sir—Miſtris Ʋoluble—

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Is the widow come?

sp.speaker: I Ieer.
sp.p: The Gentlewoman is come, and de|ſires to ſpeake with your worſhip in private.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The Curat's in the Hall ſir.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: So, ſo, I muſt intreate your patience for a few minutes; how I am bleſt! Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Tell a me de trot, have you no Argent, no portion?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: But I have a trade.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I dare be ſworne thou haſt.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Aw dat is ſometing, here is my hand, you no tell a de tale, a me, and me keepe your Enter Sir William, and Mother.
ſecret by my trot.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I tooke boldneſſe Madam upon ſight of your Ladiſhips new Coach at the doore, to entrude and preſent a poore forſaken ſervant; give you joy of your old faſhion'd young Gentle|man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your companion wants no antiquity, if ſhe have no Viſard on.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I hope you are not married Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The matters done, and tis more honourable to make a Lady than to marry one. Does any body know this Gentlewoman, ſhe was a widow till this morning, and a rich one I thanke my ſtaires, and wants the ſubtile art, ſome Ladyes have to make themſelves ridiculous, by doting upon anticks.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What name has your moſt reverend Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: She was called the wealthy widow of old Simpleton, before I married her.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What Is't makes you ſo merry Mounſieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar ſome body make arrant aſſe of de Knight, hold a me, or me ſhall cracke a my rib wi'de laugh, dat is no Simplaton, but an autre Chambermaid, de ſervant to my vife, begar he be ſheated too.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I muſt confeſſe ſhe waited upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ma foy dat is certaine, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I deſie her, that was but a plot.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Begar it was very fine a plot, me have
patience, dat dere be more foole in de come|dy.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Miſtris Ʋoluble can juſtifie what I am, that I am, or would I might nere be, a Lady, and I be'nt, that I be'nt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I will have Juſtice.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You may have him ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuſtice
sp.p: The reaſon of this noyſe my right worſhipfull?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Give me a warrant preſently.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Againſt whom?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Ʋol●ble, I'le have her whip'd.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Wrong not the vertuous Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Vertuous? vexation.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why doe you take on ſo, o' my conſci|ence ſhe is honeſt enough; does this woman looke like a whore?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I thanke you Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She has gravity enough to be a bawde, and then the worſt is paſt.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Is not the widow weight, not perfect ſterling?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: This is not the widow.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: What widow?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: The rich widow Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: I doe believe it, did ſhe promiſe you marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: The devills proctor Miſtris Ʋoluble made me believe ſo.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
Doe not wrong I ſay agen that vertuous Gentlewoman Miſtris Ʋoluble, I know her, and know her vertuous, but the rich widow Simpleton, you talke of (thankes be to providence) is
newly married, the Prieſt hath ſcarce wip'd his oraculous lips, ſince they pronounc'd us, Man Enter Ʋoluble, and two Ieerers (at one doore) Simpleton, at the other.) and Wife, in my ſtone Parlour, in good faith la, ſhe's here, her owne tongue will confirme it Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why does ſhe veile her face.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: It is her modeſty, to hide her bluſhes, that I ſhould ſo ſoone prevaile upon her: and thus the morning breakes out of the cloudes.

sp.speaker: ●impl.
sp.p: By your leave Landlady, wher's my mother.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Miſtris Ʋoluble?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Here's my ſon, he ſhall be a witneſſe I am his mother, I am married to this Knight, and they would perſwade me out of my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis come about agen, Is this your mother?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I have asked her bleſſing in my dayes.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: There is no remedy, 'twas your owne Curate did it.

sp.speaker: Ieer
sp.p: Give you joy Mr. Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Conſpiracy, is there no law for this?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the canon law, and you muſt keepe her.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Let me obtaine Madam your faire con|ſtruction, Sir William you are ſped to your deſires, and you are fitted Mounſieur Galliard, but Nice, the Jewells muſt returne to their right owner.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Excuſe a moy.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: It muſt be ſo, I keepe my wedding ring for thee ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
I aske you pardon ſir, and Miſtris Lucy,
I had a plot upon your loves, to endeare young Simpleton, in hope your credulous nature, to avoid melancholy, might have beene engag'd to ſome licentious rudeneſſe, and ſo made your ſelf unworthy of her affection, but here I muſt con|feſſe I have no skill in ſtarres nor fortune telling, and am but one among the reſt that have de|ceiv'd your eaſy faith, forgive me, as I wiſh you may thrive in your affections.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I am confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay then let marriages goe round, with this take both poſſeſſion of my heart and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You but inlarge my power to doe you ſervice.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Your love, and joyes be conſtant. Mr. Iuſtice you muſt embrace Miſtris Ʋoluble.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: VVell, I will love thee for thy wit; but no more wandring.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: You wholly ſir ſhall ſteere me, and to invite more welcome from you ſir, I have not liv'd upon the common charity, I have a ſtate is not to be deſpis'd.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Saiſt thou ſo, wee'l put our ſtocks to|gether and live merrily.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Will they not take his word? alas poore Formall, there, there's their ranſome, bid the whore be honeſt, I'le plead his reconcilement to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ieere Ma.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But d'ee heare, muſt I ha' no wench, at the end of the play? that have taken all this paines? what will you doe with me?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
Well remembred, this Lady did accuſe
him; though I miſſ'd of the Mother, I will make ſure of the ſon, make his warrant for New|gate preſently.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: I know how very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You call'd it love before, I freely pardon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Let this Day be conſecrate to peace, and Hymen.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: And the Night to Ʋenus; let it be ſo, and thanke this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thanke you all, and will never truſt a witch for your ſake, I'le goe ſeeke out my wits.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Let no man part, ſo many hearts here tid'd,
Stay till we drinke a health to every Bride.
